Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6234, file 511-5, part 6)
We wish to refer to Mr. Neary's letter July 6th 1948 file 136-2-5 (El) in connection with the purchase of a Dresser, Wash stand, Basin and pitcher Kitchen stove and toilet (indoor).

The stove is in very bad condition and should be replaced if at all possible. It is dangerous and useless to bake with. A dresser is also required for one of the bedrooms. In regard to the wash stand, we have an old one in the Clerks Residence which could be utilized. Basin and pitcher, and toilet may be omitted for now.

Some repairs are coming for the pump which will not cost much. The sink and the school fence can also be omitted for the time being.

for P G Lazenby
Sup't: Fisher River Agency
September 17, 1948.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, you may purchase a stove for the teacher's quarters at the Fisher River School.

A suitable stove should be purchased and the cost should be kept as low as possible.

In future, when making requests for equipment or repairs you should state the expenditure that will be involved.

You may also purchase a reasonably priced dresser.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Attached is an account covering the cost of a stove purchased for the Fisher River Day School teacher's residence.

The old stove is in very bad condition and it was necessary to secure a new one as soon as possible.

Please issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: 516-511-12-415.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD
We would be pleased to be advised as to the disposition of old stoves now being replaced at the Fisher River Indian Day School, and at South Peguis School.

Some of the Indians would like to buy them, while there are some destitute Indians who could make good use of them.

Please advise.

S Boyne
A/Supt
October 27, 1948.

Mr. J. Boyne,
Assistant, Indian Agency,
In Charge Fisher River Agency,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, the old stoves in the Fisher River and South Peguis Schools should be given to destitute Indians.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re New Fence Posts for Fisher River School

The fence posts at this school need to be replaced, many are down and the others are completely rotten at the base. We will require about 114 posts and some fourteen rails. A total cost of not more than $25.00.

The best time of the year to get these posts is now, during the winter, as the muskegs are too soft and wet in the spring and summer, and best posts are available in these muskegs.

The work cannot be done until this spring, and we estimate it will cost $25.00 to cover labour. However, this money will not be required until then, but we would appreciate an accountable advance of $25.00 to cover the cost of the posts.

S Boyne

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary,

The two furnaces in the Fisher River two room Day School are in very poor condition, and will have to be replaced at once, as they are beyond repair. I had Mr. Campbell of the Campbell Heating Company check them over, and I am attaching herewith his letter - giving a quotation on two new furnaces. These furnaces are very hard to get, and Mr. Campbell advises me that they could only secure a #21 and a #23.

I am unable to get another price on these furnaces, as the firms will not go to Hodgson to check the furnaces. However, I consider Mr. Campbell's price of $1,615.00 quite reasonable, as these are large furnaces and a lot of new piping will have to be fitted in the basement.

Will you please advise me as soon as possible regarding this matter, as this school has been newly decorated last summer, and it is impossible to use the present furnaces without smoking up the building; also they might cause a fire at any time. I would appreciate it if you would wire a reply, so I can have these furnaces installed without further delay.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge your letter No. 117576 dated the 14th September, 1917.

This is with reference to a change of Teacher in the Fort Alexander (Upper) Day School. I would be obliged if I could read the request of the Indians in this matter, as I, from what I know, do not think there is any good reasonable ground for this request. I was present at a meeting where this matter was mentioned, but I intimated that I could not agree with them, as I felt they were not acting right. I have always found the present teacher, the Rev. C.H. Fryer very kind to the children and to the parents, occasions do arise where he has to act with some firmness, but I feel sure that he always tempers his action with justice and kindness. He will not accept any dictation from the Indians in the disposal of the destitute relief, and this is resented. I have found that his judgement in this destitute business, is invariably good, and the supplies used under his direction are used to the best advantage. His independance in not listening to the Indians, has made them feel unkindly, and they think they will have the handling of this if they can get Mr. Fryer out of the way. I am pretty well certain that a clique want to get an Indian by the name of Jeremiah Henderson, Son of Counsellor John Henderson in as teacher; this man was an utter failure at Black River, and I think that it is not possible to compare him to Mr. Fryer in any way as a teacher. And then again Mr. Fryer acts in a very acceptable and capable manner as dispenser, he is patient and works hard for the whole of the people in this work and does good service. The scheming against Mr. Fryer is not a unanimous wish of the Band and I have no hesitation in claiming that it would be hard to get as good a man to do the work that Mr. Fryer does so well and so attentively for these people, and many of them are his friends and are grateful.
to him. I would not entertain their request, and cannot endorse it at all. This is a matter that they have been agitating in a small clique, but so far as I know is not wide in its influence among them. Mr Fryer will not take any notice of this ingratitude but he endeavors to smooth it down, some of the Indians take this as a mark of fear, which is a great mistake, as Mr Fryer's record with the Band is able to stand any fair enquiry. I would suggest to this Band that the Department is well satisfied with Mr Fryer's services, and that reports corroborate this. I might also say that if you wish to look further into this matter, I would refer you to Inspector Bunn.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

REPORT FOR MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1941.

VISITING RESERVES

I visited Fort Alexander Reserve and found most of the Indians were cutting pulpwood and a few of them were winter fishing on Lake Winnipeg and a number had been employed in the Manitoba Paper Company wood camps in the District. I visited the R.C.S. School and found conditions very favourable. I also visited the Day School where I made arrangements regarding wood and arranged to have a new flag pole erected to replace the broken pole. I visited Indian homes and found that the material which the Department has supplied has been put to good use in repairing homes. Some of the homes visited were in good condition and the Indians had made good use of the whitewash supplied but others were not so well kept. I also discussed the matter of our storehouse with Mr. C.C. Irvine. I visited our Hospital and found conditions favourable. I visited Brokenhead Reserve. The Indians on this Reserve are busy cutting cordwood and some of them have gone to the bush camps. Many of these Indians had good gardens and have sufficient vegetable for the Winter months and the Indians who have farms have sufficient flour to last them for a year.

E. McPherson,

It is quite possible that Mrs. Anderson was substituted for Mrs. Taylor, but, if so, we certainly would like to know.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Your file 125-19-1, November 2nd.

The teacher in charge of the Fort Alexander Indian Day School is Mrs. J.B. Taylor. I made the error through a misunderstanding. Mrs. Taylor had a Mrs. Anderson visiting her the day I called.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

February 2nd, 1926.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge cheques No. 5660 and 5661 being December quarter salary for teachers at Fort Alexander and Hollow Water River.

I have noticed of late that cheques for the quarter have been $45.00 in excess of the amount formerly sent for this purpose and the September cheque has been $15.00 more than former cheques for that period.

I learn indirectly that the former bonus has now definitely been added to the salary, which would account for the increased amount received by me. Would you kindly let me know if this is so. I should be obliged if you would also state the amount of the salary of the teachers at Fort Alexander, Hollow Water River, Jack River and Black River. This latter is, I understand, paid direct. I simply desire to have this information on file as from you.

Yours Faithfully,

[Signature]

Secretary-Treasurer.
Ottawa, February 5, 1926.

Very Reverend Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, I beg to say that previous to March 31, 1925, teachers at Indian day schools were allowed bonus at the rate of $15 a teaching month in addition to their regular salary. Payment of this bonus was discontinued from April 1, 1925, and the salary of each teacher was increased by $150 for the ten teaching months.

From April 1st last salaries at the following rate have been paid to the teachers of the schools you mention in your letter -

Fort Alexander.............. $750
Hollowwater River........... 750
Jack River.................. 650
Black River.................. 650

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Canon J. Lofthouse,
Synod Office,

Ottawa, October 24, 1927.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 19th instant, with further reference to Mrs. G. R. Harbord's acceptance of the Fort Alexander Indian Day School. Mrs. Harbord possesses a teacher's certificate, and further, I have been given to understand that her husband is not physically fit for onerous duties at the present time. This is why the appointment was offered to Mrs. Harbord. You may inform her, however, that they may divide the classroom duties between them whenever it is considered advisable so to do, provided the progress of the pupils meets with no interference.

As other arrangements have been made for the missionary activity on the reserve, the Department will allow Mrs. Harbord a salary of $85 per teaching month.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School, No. 518.

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Mrs. Marjorie B. Hunter, effective July 1, 1945; and no further salary should be paid to her after that date. To succeed her we have approved the appointment of Mrs. Gladys Cline at a salary of $85.00 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective September 1, 1945.

I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the other documents will be forwarded to you when received.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
April 28, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY
Re: Fort Alexander Day School
No. 318

It has been decided to dispense with the services of Mrs. Gladys A. Climo, effective July 1, 1946. No further payment of salary should be made to her after that date.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
May 19, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School, No. 513.

In my memorandum of April 28, I advised you that the services of Mrs. Gladys A. Cline would terminate on July 1, 1946.

To succeed her the Department has appointed Miss Ida G. Fairservice at a salary of $95 a teaching month, effective September 1, 1946. I enclose copy of letter of appointment.

Miss Fairservice has been in charge of the Kettle Point Indian Day School for the academic year 1945-46 and consequently is being transferred to Fort Alexander and, therefore, new forms will not be necessary for her.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, November 17, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School,
No. 512.

Mrs. Jennie Parker Taylor has been appointed teacher of the above-mentioned school, effective October 8, 1945, at a salary of $95.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. I enclose copy of letter of appointment, also T.D.I form and cost-of-living bonus form. Staff questionnaire will reach you shortly.

For Deputy Minister.

Enc.

Dear Sir:

Dr. Dorsey has been informed of our decision in this regard and is nominating a returned veteran at present attending normal school.

Yours very truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Frank J. Joblin,
Georgina Island, Ontario.

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School No. 512.

for Deputy Minister.

Ottawa, June 23, 1947.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School, No. 512.

At the above school Miss Elizabeth Turner has been appointed as a teacher, Indian school, Grade III. Effective 1 September, 1947, her salary will be $1,440.00 per academic year, in accordance with the regulations of our Indian school teachers' salary schedule as approved by Treasury Board.

Miss Turner is a spinster and has no dependents. Therefore Income Tax T.D.1 form was returned incomplete. Miss Turner taught at the Little Red River Day School in 1945-46 and her staff questionnaire is already on file.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter No.125-195 of July 13th last, I beg to report that the building at the Fort Alexander Indian Day School is in fair condition, and the location is about central for the children attending. It is a frame building and is situated about two miles East from the Anglican Mission. The teacher, Rev. C.H. Fryer, desires to have the school closer to the Mission and it would be more convenient. Due to the proposed erection of a Pulp Mill on the same side of the school, I consider that it would be advisable to have the school two miles further away.

The cost of moving this building would be approximately $200.00 and the proper time to do this work would be during the winter months.

I am informed that the Church authorities would grant a school site on their Mission land.

Hoping that this report will be satisfactory.

Sir:

I have your letter of 9th instant relative to the moving of the school building at the Fort Alexander Indian Day School to a new site on the Church of England Mission property. We note that the cost of moving this building would be approximately $200.00 and that the proper time to do the work would be during the winter months.

You should again bring this matter to the attention of the Department when considered timely for the moving of the building and you should state whether a site could not be secured nearer the Mission property. This Department will hesitate to place the building on a site which it does not own.

At the time of my visit school was not in progress as the newly appointed teacher had not arrived.

The residence for the teacher was completed and the furniture had arrived. This house is of log construction, about 18 x 24. The floors have not been well laid and the nails, instead of being driven through the tongue of the flooring, are simply driven straight down through the floor and consequently all the nail heads show. Finishing nails were not used so that these nail heads are quite noticeable. The house consists of one room downstairs and one up.

The school building is in need of paint. The inside porch needs repair as the plaster has fallen off in patches. Beaver board would perhaps give the best service in this entrance. The classroom is quite large, but was badly in need of cleaning. The blackboard is little better than paper and only about 10 ft. long. A new blackboard, 18 ft. long, would be of great assistance to the teacher.

Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 125-19-5 of 19th instant, re-Inspector Hamilton's report on the Fort Alexander upper Indian day School and note recommendations for improvements and repairs. I regret that it is too late to have these repairs done during the Xmas holidays, but will have this done during Easter and will have the material on the ground in good time.

I visited the school on 20th instant, and found a marked improvement under the new teacher, Mrs. Harbord. There are at present 26 pupils on the roll, with an average attendance of 16. The blackboard material can be secured any time and put up. I expect to visit the reserve on 9th January and will take the correct measurements.

Mr. and Mrs. Harbord, the teachers, are very much disappointed in the school residence. It is built of logs and hard to heat and keep warm. The residence at North Peguis, where they taught before, was a frame building and very comfortable and, naturally, they feel up against it in a log building. This building was built on the specifications and under the supervision of Mr. Fryer, the late teacher and Anglican clergyman. The department supplied the lumber and the Indians did the work, rations being given them while at work. I cannot say that it is a first class job and quite agree with Inspector Hamilton's report.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:—

On a recent inspection of Fort Alexander Indian Day School, Mrs. Harbord, the teacher, informed me that the supply of biscuits for the children's mid-day meal was nearly finished. In explanation, I beg to refer you to my letter of 10th April last and your reply, No. 125-19-5, of 18th April, informing me that the annual supply of biscuits were being forwarded from Regina. On receiving this shipment, I forwarded 200 lbs to Fort Alexander to tide them over for the term ending 31st June. On August 28th, I sent another 400 lbs, which was 150 lbs more than the estimates for the Fort Alexander Day school called for. I found that I could take this amount from Black River Day School, as they had a surplus over from the previous year.

The attendance at Fort Alexander School has more than doubled in the past year, and the teacher is doing splendid work and giving great satisfaction. The day I visited the school 27 children were present, with over 30 on the roll. The attendance of the younger children will probably decrease during the cold weather, but the average attendance should be at least 20, which would mean in biscuits ration 100 lbs per month, or 600 lbs more until the end of the term.

In the Estimates for 1929-30 the supply for Fort Alexander was estimated at 900 lbs, (exactly double the amount from the previous year) but even this, with the present attendance will not be sufficient.

I would strongly recommend that the extra 900 lbs. be granted and trust you will approve of the expenditure.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

come to school, especially if it is stormy. The same thing applies in the winter time; small children have to be driven to school, and very often it is impossible for the parents to do this. One of the old Indians, for the past few years, has been bringing the children across in the summer time in his boat, without receiving any remuneration whatever, but he is now too old to do this. The cost of this would be much less than operating a day school on each side of the river, and I am sure it would be much more satisfactory. It would also eliminate the chance of a serious accident happening in cases where several children have been in the habit of coming across the river in a boat by themselves.
FORT ALEXANDER DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

At the time of my visit there were 50 children on the roll, and an average attendance for the year of about 20.

The school itself is in a very dilapidated condition; it is 39 years since it was built, and it is in such a state that it is impossible to repair it without spending more money than the building is worth. A new school was asked for, and I wish to point out that this is one of the places where a new building is certainly required.

There is also another matter which I would like to place before the Department, viz; the Protestant Indians are asking that another day school be built across the river, where, with the children now coming of school age, I believe there would be in the neighbourhood of 20 children coming from there. I understand this has already been brought to the attention of the Department.

I am of the opinion that the most economical and satisfactory way of meeting this situation would be to build a new school on the site of the old school, which I have already mentioned is urgently required, and where there is a new teacher's residence, and that the Department make arrangements for some reliable Indian to bring all the children across the river in a boat in the summer time, and by sleigh in the winter. The river is at least half a mile wide at this point, and it is dangerous to allow the children to come alone. It is also a difficult matter for the parents to spare time to bring their children across every morning as they have to work hard for a living, and therefore, very often the children do not...

This school is operated under the auspices of the Anglican church, and is in charge of Mrs. Charles Harbord. I have never inspected this school before, but I am very well acquainted with Mrs. Harbord's work as she taught for some time on the Peguis Reserve, in the Fisher River Agency, and she has always given satisfaction. Mr. & Mrs. Harbord are doing splendid work at Fort Alexander.

Dear Sir,

I requisitioned at the end of last quarter i.e. on June 30th, for a store for the Fort Alexander Days School as the present one is so dilapidated as to be unsafe, but have not received it or heard anything about it so far.

I would also like to draw your attention to the state of the building. The plaster of the ceiling is coming down in heaps, every rainstorm makes it worse as the roof is open.

I think you have realized the condition of the walls; the rotten state of the woodwork makes it so draughty.
that last winter I received several letters from parents requesting me not to let their children sit near the wall as they got so cold. I quite saw their point; it was perfectly true, but when I changed their places, as we had to keep a big fire to make the school possible at all—their faces were scorched.

Of course I quite see that repairing a building as dilapidated as old is this—it is 39 years old—is a waste of money, even if it is possible. I simply wish to ask if I have your authority to close the school in severe weather if I consider it advisable.

Yours truly,
M. C. Hartford

Selkirk, Man., February 3, 1941.

Dear Sir:

We have received a petition from the Indians residing on the East side of the River on the Fort Alexander Reserve, requesting a school on their side of the River. They have requested that we forward their petition to the Department. Some of the families who have signed this petition have no children at all and of the 21 children belonging to those signing the petition, several are not of school age.

I would not recommend that a school be built at the present time but I would recommend that consideration be given to the hiring of an Indian to take these children back and forth across the River by boat as it is dangerous for children to be on the river alone in a boat. Possibly some arrangement could also be made for an Indian to take these children to school by team in the Winter time. If the Department will consider some arrangement as suggested here, I will try and arrange for a man to do this work.

Dear Mr. Hogg:

I taught for several years in the New Canadian schools when you were the minister of Education of Manitoba. My last school was the senior school at Pine River, with Mr. J. E. B. Dunlop as principal trustee. Mr. Fletcher recommended me to Bishop Lipton, head of this school, and Mr. Adna Brown had been teaching in my school in Ottawa. They both advised me to try it for a year or two.

I find the Indian children very musical, but there is no musical instrument except the school. Since the last teacher asked for a gramophone and records, could you help me in the matter of a gramophone and records? I consider it very much needed— I bought the rhythm sticks for a rhythm band myself from Ottawa. The children are playing by the tunes.

Ottawa, November 19, 1942.

Dear Mrs. Hunter:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant and to state that I was glad to learn that you had taken charge of the Fort Alexander Indian Day School. May I express the hope that you will find the work interesting and well worth while.

The records here indicate that it has not been the policy of the Department to purchase gramophones for Indian day schools anywhere in the Dominion, and of course in a period such as this all expenditures have been substantially reduced. I am anxious, however, to do everything possible to encourage you to help your pupils. Therefore, if you can secure from Eaton's or from any other source a gramophone with records at a cost not to exceed $50.00, you are authorized to make the purchase. The bill for this purchase should be sent forward to the Department in duplicate.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

In October I wrote to Mr. M. Pearson, the agent in regard to the well. There is very little water and I do not all use! I am enclosing his answer. As he requested I sent in the triplicate requisition forms for supplies. It was not acknowledged.

In December I wrote him again in regard to materials for handwork. I also enclosed his reply. Whether he replied, the requisition or destroyed it I cannot say. However I sent triplicate requisitions again asking for a new register—construction paper etc. That was not acknowledged either.

I have had to buy all materials I have used for manual—sewing and handwork. I am enclosing a list of some of these things as I feel the Department should pay for them.

Since Christmas I have had 18 to 20 pupils each day. Mr. Walters says this is more children than have ever attended—that
is encouraging—

Would you see I had
a news register—continued Dec. 28/42.

2 packages of construction paper (assorted colors)
2 packages of paper for paper folding & cutting
200 sheets of drawing paper

I will try to make this do till the
end of June when I will be through here!
I promised to give the Indian work a
fair trial so am trying to stay here
and do good work till Feb. end of June
1943.

As my daughter is assistant minister
at Young Church—bringing the Y.P.M. News
out and the toys and candy for the tree.
I provided the decorations etc.

Thank you for the cod liver oil—
giving each child a dessertspoonful at

improvement I think!

Yours respectfully,

Marjorie B. Hunter.

Dear Mrs. Hunter:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, I have reviewed our files and find that we received a requisition from you dated October 30, 1942. This arrived here on November 6 and the Stationery Office was requested to supply the following:

- 2 Copies "Junior Handicraft"
- 6 Boxes water colours
- 1 Ream foolscap

There were other articles requested, such as poster paper, construction paper and plasticine, but we have not been supplying these due to difficulty in securing some of the articles and in the second place we have been trying to keep expenditure as low as possible.

We have also received a requisition from you dated December 6. This arrived here on December 21 and the Stationery Office was requested to supply 12 sets of number cards and strips, 12 sets of letter builders and 6 boxes water colours. A daily register was also ordered on this requisition and was sent to you on December 28.

I note that the letters which Indian Agent McPherson sent to you were addressed to Fort Alexander, Man. On the two requisitions we received from you you stated that the post office address was Pine Falls, Man. Consequently the articles ordered from the Stationery Office and the school register which was sent from this office were addressed to you at Pine Falls, Man. It has occurred to me that possibly there is mail awaiting you at Pine Falls which, as stated above, was the post office address to which you stated the articles should be sent.

Mrs. Marjorie B. Hunter,
Teacher, Fort Alexander Indian Day School,
Pine Falls, Man.

P.S.G.
With reference to the attached account, the Department is prepared to arrange repayment to you, but before doing so, in view of present regulations, we will have to have the actual accounts from the firms from whom you purchased the articles and, of course, to allow payment to be made to you these accounts will have to be receipted. No doubt you have these and if you forward them I will arrange for a refund.

While, as stated above, we have not been supplying construction paper and folding paper, it has been decided, in view of your special request, to order these and a requisition for same is being sent to the Stationery Office today. It will probably be some time before you receive them because, as you are aware, present conditions make it impossible for firms to assure prompt deliveries.

I am writing to Mr. McPherson to see if anything could possibly be done to improve the water supply.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Mr. McPherson was speaking about fixing the well when he was here. I think it would be foolish to pay the Indians to dig another hole and put in more pipe. There should be a well drilled by a man who understands the work. The well here is just a 'surface' well. In the fall there were bugs and flies floating around in the water. One thing that is very necessary here is good water. As you know the river water is condemned—it is filled with germs.

If a 'well driller' would reach good water it would mean a great deal not only to the school but to the district.

Thank you,

Yours respectfully,

M.B. Hunter
R.A. Hoey: Sup't of Welfare and Training:

Re: Pump at Fort Alexander School.

I have just returned from a trip to Fort Alexander reserve and while there I inspected the school and interviewed Mrs. Hunter. I did not inform her that I had received a letter from you regarding the water but in our conversation I asked her if she was getting a good enough supply of water for her own use. She informed me that she was but that when she returned to school after the Christmas holidays, there was no water in the well. She knew that the Indians had been using the well while she was away and she informed them that they were not to do so. Since then she has had sufficient water.

I feel satisfied that when spring comes, we should extend the pipe down another ten feet to assure a plentiful supply for her and the Indians living close to the school. I wish you would please give me permission to do this when the warm weather comes.

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 6, 1943.

Dear Mrs. Hunter:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 31, in which you intimate that in your judgment a well driller should be employed to deepen the well at your school.

You will readily appreciate that it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to undertake a project of this nature unless provision has been made for such work in the annual estimates. It so happens that no provision was made for the construction of a well at the Fort Alexander Day School, either in the estimates of this year or next year. I feel it is unnecessary to add that in view of the critical times in which we are living, it is exceedingly difficult, also, to secure funds for the regular services. However, I am communicating today with Indian Agent McPherson, in the hope that a small amount may be available from some source to deepen the well. I would imagine it would be almost impossible to proceed with the work until the weather moderates.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. Marjorie B. Hunter,
Teacher,
Fort Alexander Indian Day School,
Pine Falls, Manitoba.

I was at the Fort Alexander Indian Day School early in October and would recommend the following repairs:

1. The erection of a fence along the top of the river bank to keep out the Indian cattle. I would suggest a four-strand barbed wire fence with plenty of good posts. It will require two spools of wire and perhaps thirty posts. Material approximately $14.00 and about $6.00 for labor.

2. The teacher's residence needs interior decoration. The walls and ceilings are badly smoked and dirty. Mrs. Cline, the teacher, does not request expensive decoration but would like the walls repaired and tinted. It is hard to get men for such work but I believe Mr. Irvine might release a man if Mr. McPherson had the necessary authority. The floors also should be painted.

I would recommend that the Agent be instructed to proceed with this work at once.

Next year the school and residence should be painted outside. Unfortunately Mr. McPherson overlooked this in his estimates. If it is not too late I would suggest $350.00 be inserted to cover the material and work. The school was painted inside this summer and the work was well done. The room is now much brighter and will be more pleasant both for the teacher and pupils.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

My dear Mr. Ferrier,

Re Indian Day School at Fort Alexander.

As you are aware we are hoping to have a school teacher to take up the work in this school after the summer holidays in place of Rev. C. H. As I have learned that both Commissioner Graham and the Deputy Supt are away and will likely be absent for some little time, I thought it best to write you so that the matter may go through the proper channel. I leave for the North shortly and would appreciate an early reply.

Most truly,

Dear Sir,

With regard to the teacher's residence at the Fort Alexander Day School, instead of being able to improve the house as we thought, we can do nothing and it gets continually worse.

It is extremely repugnant to me to complain as I appreciate your efforts to make the house habitable for us, but it seems impossible to effect any improvement.

Owing no doubt to the time of year the mudding up was done, the frost and wind crack the mud which is constantly falling from between the logs both inside and out, creating terrible draughts, dangerous to a man suffering from bronchitis, as my husband does, due to overseas service.

For the same reason we cannot improve the barn-like interior or give it any appearance of comfort, as hammering a nail brings down a shower of mud and lime, the dust of which is very painful and injurious to affected bronchial tubes. After a fall of snow we have to shovel snow out of the house as the roof is open.

Apart from the acute discomfort, the fact that we live in a house, similar to, but not as good as some on this Reserve, and have to cook, eat and sleep in the one room, will lower our prestige with these people and ruin all hopes of successful work.

We are sure the Department wishes the school and its surroundings to do them credit, but one cannot do their best work living in such conditions.

I should be obliged if you would bring my remarks to the notice of the Department without delay.

The matter of a proper water supply and of an outhouse, both of which are entirely lacking, can be taken up later.

I am,
Yours truly,
(signed) M.C. Harberd.

Funds necessary for replacement of the teacher's residence at the Fort Alexander Indian Day School were not included in the Estimates for the current fiscal year. Mr. Commissioner Graham pointed out, in January, that the house was not fit for habitation, and he strongly urged that a building be provided. You allowed an appropriation for a new school building at Enderby, B.C., and, with the Fort Alexander need in mind, I did not send out any authority to Mr. Indian Agent Ball in May. During the summer, there has been no repetition of the request for this school, and I believe that its erection can be safely postponed.

This will release funds for the erection of the Fort Alexander teacher's residence, and, as we have a very satisfactory teacher there now, whose husband is a physically unfit returned soldier, I am quite eager to do something for them.

Sir,

I cannot speak with any enthusiasm about the work of the Methodist Church at this point. It was commenced some 8 years ago practically and it has not been maintained with any degree of efficiency and at the present it is an unoccupied field no one not even a school teacher being on the ground.

There is a Missionary's House very poor indeed and a church which is hardly worthy of the name. There are a few houses very few indeed in the vicinity of the Mission. The Indians are hunters for the most part and are only near in summer and in the great Holidays such as Christmas and New Year. They live for the most part in old fashioned wigwams and are camped in sequestered places all winter where the north winds are harping over the pines lyrics learned when the world was young.

Besides the people have chosen their reserve a full days journey from the site of the Mission station and if their request carries it will be necessary to move all the Methodist people have at Gods Lake or forsake it and build anew.

I could not therefore recommend that a School be built at Gods Lake at present. Better wait until it is known where the Band will be located and then build wisely and well.

I have the honor to enclose the return of the God's Lake U. Church Day School for the months from June 22nd to Sept. 4th. The school was open for 56½ days, 7½ of these days being Saturdays. There were 48 pupils on the roll, and the average attendance was 19.28.

Dear Sir:

Re: Gods' Lake School.

For two years we have been conducting an experiment at Gods' Lake by sending in a summer teacher. Five years ago the Indians were quite sure that they preferred a native evangelist to a white missionary-teacher, and, at their request, the missionary-teacher was removed. Since Mr. Morley Coleman went in to teach the summer school they have seen their mistake, and on several occasions recently have petitioned us to send them a missionary-teacher. We have a good house, in which the missionary could live, and a new church, just completed, which we would be willing to use temporarily as a school-room.

The discovery of gold in that area has led to quite an influx of prospectors and miners, and reports reaching us from Winnipeg are to the effect that many others are preparing to go in as soon as spring opens up. It would seem, therefore, as if the time were ripe to provide the Indians of Gods' Lake with a better type of leadership for their own protection than the Indian evangelist who is there now can give them.

We are in communication with two or three young men who are graduating in Arts and Theology at Manitoba University in June and who would be in a position to teach the school in a most efficient way and at the same time give counsel and advice to the band, which they are sorely needing in their new and sudden contacts with an influx of white settlers.

We ask therefore that in the preparation of the budget for 1933-4, an amount be included as from July 1st to cover the salary of a missionary-teacher at Gods' Lake.

I have not had the opportunity of getting a written communication from Mr. Gordon, the Indian Agent at Norway House, in regard to this matter, but I know from conversation with him that it has his hearty endorsement.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Dear Sir:

Re: Nomination of Teacher for Gods' Lake.

On the occasion of my last visit to Ottawa, I discussed at considerable length with Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Phelan the question of conducting a summer school at Gods' Lake in Northern Manitoba, as has been done for the last two years. It was decided that, if we could find a missionary-teacher of the right type, it would be preferable to have him go in to stay for the full year. We have a new and very comfortable church building there now, which can be used as a school-room.

I wish to nominate for the position of teacher at Gods' Lake Mr. Fred W. Stevens. My understanding is that the grant will be at the rate of $90.00 a month, beginning September 1st. Mr. Stevens, as you will remember, was at Oxford House for two years. Since then he has taken two years' Arts work at the University of Manitoba. When I was in Winnipeg recently I checked up on his work pretty closely. He has apparently grown a good deal in every way during the time that he has been in college. I know that Mr. Russell Ferrier felt that during the last year he was at Oxford House he was not over-industrious, but I am assured by those who have been closest to him that there will be no difficulty on that score now. He has been doing volunteer work with some boys' groups in one of our non-Anglo-Saxon Missions in the North end of Winnipeg and has made quite a success of it.

Mr. Stevens has a considerable speaking knowledge of Cree, which will be a decided asset in a backward community like Gods' Lake, which has been on the whole less responsive than any of our fields in Northern Manitoba.

Hoping that this nomination will meet with your approval,

I am

Yours sincerely,

On the 29th, the treaty party left Island Lake, for God's Lake, where treaty payment and census taking was commenced immediately on arrival and completed by the end of the month. Both missions were visited at this reserve and both day school teachers interviewed. The gardens at this reserve have been much neglected this year, as practically all the able bodied Indians and their families have been at the God's Lake Gold Mine, cutting fuel wood for the mines since early spring. The mine pays the Indians $4.50 per day and each ton of wood cut is delivered and $2.00 per cord if left in the bush where it is cut. Both R.C. and U.C. day schools at this reserve are 'Seasonal' schools, operating from June to September each year only. This year, owing to the Indians being at the mines, both teachers were given authority to hold their schools near the mines. The R.C. school teacher moved to the mines but was not very successful in getting attendance at the school, so moved back to the mission. The U.C. school teacher, when he heard the result of the R.C. teacher's move, remained where he was, and neither school was having much success apparently, in getting children to attend. The teachers were hoping, however, that the situation would improve during the next two months.

Dear Sir,

Dr. Carmie of the United Church Home Missions at Winnipeg has informed me that he has recommended me to your office for the position as Teacher of the God's Lake Seasonal Indian Day School. I understand that up until last year that your Department has paid the fare of the teacher in to the Lake & from Winnipeg besides the regular pay of $6 per teaching day. Upon checking up on the fare I find that the plane fare return is $17.00, but if I were to go by boat to Norway House and then from there to the Lake by plane it would be approximately $80.00. The latter way is the cheapest possible way; however it will take a week or so longer.

I would like to find out if the Indian Dept. would resume their practice of bearing the burden of this extremely high fare. You will realize
that if the teacher is to pay the fare out of his salary besides boarding himself while there he will have very little left for his summer's work as the season is so short.

I am a law student and it has been a couple of years since I taught school, so you will realize the financial situation I am in. I am not in a position to finance this trip—fare, clothes, food, etc., just at present and I believe it would be difficult trying to get a loan, as I understand the total amount of remuneration is not certain—it depends on the number of days the Indian children will attend school.

Will your Department bear the expense of the fare as it has done in former years? This summer teaching job means a great deal to me as it will help me to study another year at law school.

I trust I shall receive a favorable reply from you in the near future as I hope you will understand the position I am in. The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.:

I received a letter some time ago from Rev. Kenneth C McLeod, the United Church Missionary at the God's Lake Reserve, in connection with the God's Lake U.C. Indian Seasonal Day School. Mr. McLeod proposes that this school be made an all year round school, similar to those at Oxford House and Island Lake Reserves, and states that if this school had been in operation, there could have been an average attendance, since the school closed in September last, of at least 8 pupils, and that with the prospect of the God's Lake Gold Mines closing down this coming summer, there would no doubt be a better average attendance than this.

Before making any definite recommendation in this matter, I should like to discuss it thoroughly with the Indians who have children of school age, and find out what promise there may be of there being a good regular attendance at the school. There is also a seasonal day school at this reserve under the R.C. auspices, which in similar circumstances might also be made into a year round school, depending upon what prospects there may be of getting a good regular attendance throughout the year.

For the present therefore, I would recommend that the matter be left in abeyance until next treaty time, when I will have an opportunity of going into it very fully.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr. R.A. Hoey's letter No; 123-3-1 of the 29th ultimo, regarding a proposed change in the operating of the U.C. and R.C. seasonal Indian Day Schools at the Cod's Lake Reserve, from a 'Seasonal' basis to a ten month basis as is done at the Island Lake Reserve.

In reply, I may say that I received a letter from the United Church Missionary at Cod's Lake on this subject, and I wrote to the Department on the 5th February concerning it, and in which I recommended that the matter might be left in abeyance until I could visit the reserve next treaty time.

Without going into the matter carefully and thoroughly on the spot, discussing it with the Indians who have children of school age and finding out definitely what prospects there are of getting, and keeping up a regular attendance at both the U.C. and R.C. schools at this reserve, I should hesitate to make any definite and final recommendation in the matter, as there are so many aspects to take into consideration.

At the present time, while the Cod's Lake Gold Mine is in operation, a considerable number of the Indians are living near the mines, about 18 miles from the reserve. If, however, the mine closes down this summer, as it is rumoured, this would make a difference in the number of children available for attendance at these two schools, as the Indians with their families would move back to the reserve to live.

During the 'Seasonal' period these two schools operated last summer, the average attendance at the U.C. School was 12.29 and at the R.C. School, 6.1, but if these schools were to be carried on during the winter this average would drop, in circumstances as they are at present.

Will you please advise me if the Department is in accord with my opinion that the making of any definite recommendation should be left in abeyance until after next treaty time, which would be about the middle of August.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Manitoba.

Re: Educational Facilities at God's Lake

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

It will be satisfactory to the Department if you make a thorough investigation of educational facilities at God's Lake and at Island Lake at the time of each treaty payment. A full report on these facilities, together with any recommendations you may care to offer, should reach the Department immediately following your inspection.

There is in the Department a feeling that the educational facilities provided in many of the outlying districts should be more prominent in character. What I would particularly like to see would be a teacher or welfare and training officer appointed on a yearly basis. This man, in my judgment, should be responsible, under the agent, for the general welfare of the Indian population. He should be responsible for the distribution of rations, medicine, etc., and his wife, if he were a married man, should be encouraged to organize Indian women for the raising and distribution of vegetables, etc. There is, of course, the question of two distinct and separate groups of Indians belonging to two different churches, which presents certain difficulties. However, we should not use this condition as a pretence or an excuse for not providing better educational facilities for the Indian population. This question has been ever in our mind and, if you have an opportunity, discuss it with men experienced in missionary and educational work in these districts. I am personally convinced that we have reached a time when our educational policy in such districts should be thoroughly revised.

With further reference to Departmental letters of January 29th and February 18th last, File 123-3-1, regarding the God's Lake United Church Indian Day School, and the proposal to make this an all year round school instead of a seasonal school as at present, I believe that when I was at this reserve for treaty payment last July, this matter was discussed very fully with the Indians at a band meeting.

The matter was put to the Indians from the viewpoint of the Department, that the department was anxious to see the Indians child educated and therefore was in favor of the Department spending a lot of money to keep a school teacher there if the parents were not going to co-operate and see that their children went to school. Quite a number of the Indians said that they usually took their families with them to their winter trapping camps.

To find out just how many pupils could be expected if the school were operated all winter, I asked the Indians, both United Church and Roman Catholic, how many of them would definitely promise to send their children to school during the winter, and in response, there were promises of 17 children for the United Church school, and 2 children for the Catholic school. Here I may say that the R.C. School is not open this summer at all, and Father Daniel who is the Priest in charge of the Mission, advised me that they were unable to secure a teacher.

After due consideration of the whole matter I would recommend that the Department keep the United Church Day School open all this coming winter, and give it a trial, as out of the 17 children promised, one could expect an average quarterly attendance of about 8 or 10.

The present teacher of this school, Mr David Friesen, is getting along well but is unable to stay any later than the third week in September, after which he will be going back to University. I ask the opportunity to put my grievances before the headquarters of the Indian Department for my band of Indians and their rights. My Council has given me their authority to present any grievance that we have for our band.

My people have no education. We have about three hundred children at present fit for school but no school to take them in. We have two small schools, one on each side of the lake, Roman Catholic and Protestant, but these are too small for the present population of school-age children. We would very much appreciate a boarding school instead of the day schools, and the children from our neighbouring reserves, God's Lake and Oxford House, could also attend. All the Indians from these Reserves could benefit by a boarding school, as well as by a hospital.

I very much appreciate this opportunity to lay our grievances before the Department and will be very thankful if the Department can give consideration to our requests.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of cheque serial number O 064294 issued by the comptroller of the treasury, Central Pay Office. This cheque I believe is in payment for my teaching for the period July 1st to Sept. 4th (inclusive) at the Indian day school at Shoal Lake, Man. (the United Church Board). However, as I calculate it, so that amount is in payment for only 49 teaching days, and as you can calculate for yourself there are 55 teaching days in that period - teaching 6 days per week as is the custom up there.

Here's how I work out my calculation:

My earnings $281.74
Less housing $36.84
Leaving $244.90

At $5.00 per day, that comes out to be $\frac{244.90}{5} = 49$ days.
Now I figure you have made the mistake you have in this. If you will read the remarks I have written down the right hand side of my report you will see that the school was closed for six weeks July 31st - Aug 5th and therefore I could only honestly say that out of a possible 55 days I was only able to teach 49.

Now it was no fault I knew that the school was closed for that period in fact I closed it only on the authority of the R.O.M.P. constable who advised such action to check the spread of a measles epidemic that was raging at that time throughout the reserve. Thus, sir, I think it only right that I should have your consideration in this point and that I should receive payment for that week when I was on hand to teach but through circumstances beyond my control was unable to.

Then there is another point which I would like to raise with you about my salary and it is this. If you will check with your
records as to my total summer earnings you will see that I have earned scarcely more than $300.* and yet I am expected to pay over $70.* in income tax. Now I realize that were I employed at that job of teaching at Lake all year round then such an income tax would be only just and fair in these times — But as you know I am a university student and was employed for the period three months only and in that period couldn't possibly, and didn't actually earn the minimum $650.* I would ask therefore that you check on this with the comptroller of the treasury and if possible please obtain a rebate for me. As you can well expect university expenses are by no means trivial and unless I obtain such a rebate — and soon — I will be in very uncomfortable circumstances to say the least.

I trust that you will be able to give due and speedy consideration.
Hoping to hear from you in these regards at your earliest possible convenience,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Wm. Aitken Harvey.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant and regret that your letter of the 24th ultimo was inadvertently overlooked.

As you state, we allowed you payment for 49 days because that was the number of days that you showed on your returns that the school had been in operation. As you know, present regulations require income tax to be deducted at the source and we have no other alternative than to follow these instructions. However, as you are a student, I agree with you that your salary for the year will not place you in the income tax bracket and you can secure a refund at the end of the year by preparing a tax return and submitting it to the income tax office in your province. Subsequently you will receive from them a refund of the tax we have deducted from your salary.

Yours truly,

I was at God's Lake on Oct 20th and 21st. I held a meeting of a number of Indians at the RCMP Barracks, which is located at the Gold Mine. There is a considerable number of Indians living in or around the mine earning their living by fishing. Some of them have bought property from the Mining Co and have settled in. At the meeting a request was submitted that a school be opened. It is estimated that at least 25 children would be in regular attendance. There is a good school house belonging to the Mining Co. I interviewed the caretaker of the property and he assured me that there would be no difficulty in obtaining permission to use this school. There would be no difficulty in obtaining living accommodation for the teacher.

The request was submitted to me by Indians of the United Church and their proposition was that the school at the Narrows be closed and moved to the Mines. I suggest that the school at the Narrows be left and that another school be opened at the Mines. This would require the hiring of another teacher.

The R.C. Church when operating a school at the mines used their own buildings. As the R.C. hold a seasonal school, there would be R.C. children at the mine requiring school accommodation.

I strongly recommend that if a new school should be opened at the mines that it be a non-denominational school and that the appointment of the teacher be made by the Indian Affairs Branch so that Indians of any faith could attend.

Sympathetic consideration of this request will be greatly appreciated.

E.B. Goodman
Indian Agent.

We have received your letter of October 15 concerning the above school. We have stopped all payment of salary to Miss Loewen and have written to her requesting that she return to us the overpayment of salary she received.

The question which you raise, concerning school administration, can best be answered by saying that the United Church has in this instance the privilege of nominating teachers for this school but that the Indian Affairs Branch has the power of appointment and dismissal. Normally this is done by the Head Office of the Branch, due to the distances involved and the relatively poor communications. This does not apply to all day schools, as there are many where the teachers are appointed by the Department, upon the recommendation of the Indian Agent.

I hope this clarifies the situation in your mind. In all other matters these schools are under your administration and should be opened and closed upon dates to be decided by you after reference to the Branch. In practically all circumstances we will accept the recommendation of the agent as to the opening and closing date of these schools, although we would prefer that they should conform to the dates laid down in our circular letter C-150-45. This was done in the case of this school, as recommended in your letter File 15 A of December 26, 1945.

We have written to the Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada concerning the closing of this school.

This is a notable achievement for Mr. Indian Agent Goodman. We have the use of a well-appointed school by paying insurance on it! We should supply a fire-extinguisher.

I assured Mr. Goodman that you would approve a modest outlay for urgently needed kitchenware and a small cookstove.

Fuel wood may cost much more than the usual $5 a cord. Single logs have to be carried on the shoulder a quarter of a mile uphill from the water.

In such matters our administrative procedures may well be modified to permit our isolated local representatives power to make on-the-spot decisions that will receive the quick endorsement of senior administrators.

I recommend that Mrs. Bennett (not Vipond) and other teachers who are at the mercy of casual mail service (Island Lake, Oxford Lake an example) be not penalized in salary payments because their applications for rating arrived late.

Mrs. Bennett conducts the school very creditably. She has obtained a complete set of the latest Manitoba publications on the course of studies. She is attempting to familiarize herself with the accepted teaching procedures.

The school needs a supply of:

- Biscuits

- Toothbrushes

Enrollment is 31. Six of the children who attend are non-Indians:
- 2 Sutyła children
- 2 Burton children

Mr. Sutyła, who is an energetic citizen of Polish descent, supplies a boat in which many of the Indian children are ferried across "the bay" twice daily.

Mr. Sutyła has also agreed to try to promote a working-bee among the Indians to repair two bridges so that the children may walk the road (25 minutes) when boating becomes impossible.

The other two white men have contributed little to the cause of education.

The question of joint support by the co-operating governments arises—if we wish it to.

Janitor service allowance was explained. Also "lunch money."

This school is well worth our support. It has no denominational link.

Sir;

I have the honor to enclose herewith the Quarterly Return of the God's Lake Day School for the Quarter ended Sept. 30th, 1925. This was late reaching me, but there has been no communication with God's Lake since the beginning of October until last week.

I note that the school was open 14 days out of 21 teaching days. The enrollment was large for God's Lake, and the average was good, 15.43. It is likely that will be the highest average of the year.

This school is carried on under considerable difficulty, owing to the nomadic habits of the Indians, very few remaining at home except for a very short period each year.

Dear Sir,

To-day I received a cheque from the Comptroller of the Treasury for Two Hundred three Dollars and Seventy Cents ($203.70), which I presume you must mean to be the balance of my summer salary as teacher of the United Church Indian Sessional School at God's Lake during the past summer. You will remember you sent me a cheque about the second week in August for Two Hundred Twenty-one Dollars and Twenty-five Cents ($221.25) as I had requested a part payment in order to pay back monies I had borrowed to finance the journey in there from Winnipeg and my living expenses while there.

Surely some mistake has been made in figuring out my salary as I was formerly told I would receive Five Dollars per day taught and I taught eighty-eight days during the summer, making a total salary of Four Hundred Forty Dollars ($440.00). In my report sent you about August 5th, I reported on days taught from June 4th to July 31st, which was forty-six days. In my report forwarded to you by Mr. Lazenby Indian Agent at Norway House, I reported on the period from August 1st to Sept. 16th which was 42 days. This makes a total of eighty-eight days taught and so I expected my salary to be Four Hundred Forty Dollars. Your two cheques to me, one dated approx. August 1st or 2nd and one dated Oct. 7th were for $221.25 and $203.70 respectively, which makes a total of only $424.95. This is $15.05 short of what you usually pay for eighty-eight days teaching. When you consider the expenses of plane fare to such a distant point and the living expenses in such an outlying area, you will readily see that the actual profit is not great and so $15.05 means quite a bit to me.

I have thought that maybe 2 per cent was deducted for the National Defence Tax but that is hardly possible as I am a University Student and I do not make Six Hundred Dollars per year. Even if this two per cent were deducted, that still leaves $6.05 for which there is no account.

If you have been compelled to deduct the two per cent National Defence Tax, on all monthly cheques, then to what Department do I apply for the refund of such monies as my income is much less than $600.00 per year.

Would you kindly rectify this error and send me the cheque for the balance of $15.05 or the $6.05 as the case may be, and if it is the latter please let me know to whom I must apply to receive the refund.

I am very sorry to have to bother you in this matter but that much money means a lot to a University Student and also I am anxious to know how such a mistake could happen in your Department.

I thank you for the cheque which I received to-day and trust that you will see fit to rectify any error that may have been made.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to deductions from your salary as teacher of the God's Lake U.C. Seasonal School.

Due to the fact that the daily rate of salary would result in your earning more than $1200.00 in a year this Department is obliged by law to deduct the 3% National Defence Tax. In your particular case the returns which you submitted showed that the school was in operation for 45 days from June 1 to July 31 and at the rate of $5.00 a day the amount due was $225.00. 3% was deducted for the period you were in charge of the school from July 1 to July 31 or an amount of $3.75. For the period August 1 to September 18 the return showed that the school was in operation for 42 days and the amount due you was $210.00. 3% of this amount is $6.30 which was deducted. You will note from the above that there was a total deduction for National Defence tax purposes of $10.05.

In view of your statement that your total yearly income will not exceed $600.00 you can apply for a refund of the above-mentioned amount of $10.05. Application should be made to the Inspector of Income Tax, Winnipeg, Man., from whom you can secure the forms that you will be required to complete.

Yours truly,

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 6 JULY 1949

The Committee of the Privy Council received before them a report dated 22nd June, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates, Vote 230, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools on the God's Lake Indian Reserve and on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, both in the Nelson River Indian Superintendency in the Province of Manitoba;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the God's Lake Reserve and on the Oxford House Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest......."

That the building materials for these schools have already been purchased and have been shipped by tractor trains to the sites of both schools;

That, due to the very isolated situation of both these Indian reserves, there are few builders or contractors in the area and outside contractors are not interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That, as the result of enquiries made by field officials of the Department of Mines and Resources the following labour tenders for the erection of these buildings have been obtained:

| Contractor                  | God's Lake | Oxford House |
|----------------------------|------------|--------------|
| Elmer Sabiston, Winnipeg    | $5,000.00  | $5,000.00    |
| Matthews Construction Co.  |            |              |
| The Pas                     | $5,000.00  | $5,000.00    |
| Emery Brothers, Flin Flon   | $5,000.00  | $5,000.00    |

That the lowest tenderer, namely Elmer Sabiston, of Winnipeg, has produced evidence to the effect that he will build these schools in a satisfactory way. His tender covers all transportation and boarding costs and is felt to be fair and reasonable.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources
The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the erection of the God's Lake Indian Day School and the Oxford House Indian Day School by Mr. Elmer Sabiston of Winnipeg, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each project; this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children on these reserves in time for school opening in September.

Re: Your File 138/6-1-513

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, our records show that the following balances are due on the contracts to which you refer in your letter.

1. God's Lake Narrows - Elmer Sabiston - $500.00
2. Nelson House U.C. - Matthews Const. Co. - $1,750.00

It is noted that you are not prepared to recommend at the present time that the above amounts be paid. However, your letter does not state a definite date when the remaining work will be completed by the contractors.

If at all possible, we are very anxious to have the work completed before the end of March, so that payment of any balances due can be made by the end of the current fiscal year. We have not provided any funds for the construction of these two buildings during the fiscal year 1950-51, as we expected them to be finished before that fiscal year commenced.

Please keep in touch with the situation at both schools, and let us have further information from you by March 15th. If the work at either or both schools is not completed by that time, it is our intention to request the Treasury Branch to issue cheques for the balances due, and
these cheques would be sent to you and retained by you until
the work was completed in a satisfactory manner. However,
we do not wish to adopt the latter procedure unless we are
absolutely obliged to do so.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
GOD'S LAKE U. C.

I have just returned from the Fur Conference held at The Pas. While in the north I visited Island Lake and God's Lake Schools. In connection with the God's Lake school that Mr. E. Sabiston built I have to report that this man made a very poor job of finishing this school. The floor has not been nailed properly and only one coat of paint was applied and very poorly applied. I have phoned Mr. Sabiston requesting that he come to the office. I will instruct him to return to God's Lake and finish the school properly before he can receive further payment.

----------------
Mr. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Further reference to my letter of February 8, 1950, file No. 138/6-1-513 regarding payment to Mr. E. Sabiston in connection with the God's Lake School.

Please be advised we are holding $1,000.00 on the two schools - God's Lake and Oxford House. As the Oxford House School is finished I feel that we could refund the $500.00 on this school. However, the God's Lake School has not been completed according to specifications. There is only one coat of paint on the inside of the school, the hinges put on the kitchen cupboards were old hinges and were not counter-sunk. The doors of the cupboards were very poorly done. The kitchen cupboards have only been put up with plywood without two by two's to support them.

In my opinion Mr. Sabiston should go in and finish the job at God's Lake or make arrangements with someone in the locality to do the painting before he receives final payment. I spoke to Mr. Sabiston when he was in the office recently regarding the God's Lake School but he gave me no satisfaction as to what he intended to do.

If you would forward the $500.00 cheque - this being the deposit for the Oxford House School - I will forward same on to Mr. E. Sabiston.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir:

Re: Gods' Lake School Building.

A number of years ago the Board of Home Missions erected at Gods' Lake a small log building to serve as a schoolhouse. When the forest fire destroyed the church, this building was not burned and it was used for both purposes for a time. For the last two years, however, it has not been usable and the school has been held in the new church building under very unsatisfactory conditions, as there are no desks. Mr. Fred Stevens has assured the cooperation of the Indians and they have put up a new log school building. Before this can be used, it will be necessary to buy some equipment and to screen the windows and doors, as the school must be held from June to September when the mosquitoes are at their worst.

The Board of Home Missions has already made an appropriation to provide the desks and I am writing to ask if the Department of Indian Affairs could find $200.00 to reimburse Mr. Stevens for the outlay which he has made in putting up the framework of the structure. This seems a very reasonable proposition, and, when compared with the cost of the school buildings at Oxford House and Island Lake, provides the Department of Indian Affairs with a place where the summer sessions of this day school can be held for several years at a very modest expense.

Mr. Stevens acknowledges receipt of the school supplies which were sent in to Ilford and will be forwarding to the Department the bill for transporting them from Ilford to Gods' Lake. He was disappointed to find that there was no blackboard cloth included and asks if it would be possible for the Department to send him a couple of yards by mail. He will see that it is properly framed and mounted.

Trusting that this request may meet with favorable consideration,

I am

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

KJB.MLT
Norway House, Manitoba,
August 31, 1934.

Sir:

With regard to your letter 123-3-5-August 7, and the God's Lake United Church Indian Day School, would say that I had a letter recently from Mr. Fred Stevens who is teaching there. In this letter he offers to proceed with the building of the school but suggested that he close the school although he has an attendance of thirty pupils on the day of writing, in order that he might give his full time to building. I presume his expectation was that the department would pay him his teachers salary while engaged on the building. I enclose a copy of the letter which I have written to him in reply, which letter expresses my opinion of the situation as it stands.

Until sufficient funds can be provided for the erection of a proper building which can then be suitably furnished and which could be expected to serve as a school for a considerable number of years, I am of the opinion that the church building will serve. With small expenditure this building could be fitted with tables and fairly comfortable seats, a portable blackboard and a small board and desk and it could be used during the summer months. It is unlikely that a yearly school will be practicable at God's Lake for some time to come. As a matter of fact, I am not in favor of any encouragement being given to the Indians to remain around the missions or the posts during the winter months.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,

Norway House, Man:
13th August 1942.

Sir,

When I was at the God's Lake reserve recently paying treaty, I visited the two day schools, and the teacher at the United Church school requested that some desks be provided, as there are none, the pupils using boxes to sit on and improvised tables for desks.

I would recommend that 12 double desks be provided for this school, similar to those that were supplied to the R.C. day school at the same reserve a year or two ago. These were made at the reserve from lumber bought from the R.C. Mission and cost $7.50 each complete. However, the R.C. Mission has no lumber on hand just now, and the lumber would have to be bought from the God's Lake Gold Mine at $65.00 per thousand feet. The Rev. K.C. McLeod, U.C. Missionary, has advised me that the necessary lumber could be bought at the Mine, and with the use of local labour the total desk cost would be approximately $9.00 each, making a total for the 12 desks required, $108.00.

Will you kindly advise me by return mail if this amount can be appropriated for this purpose, so that the work may be got under way as quickly as possible.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazebny,
Indian Agent.

God's Lake Narrows United Church School

The building is the old O.C. mission.
It is not worth spending much on.
Classroom is about 30' x 15'; poor floor,
lighting and heating.
Teacher's and pupils' desks are homemade.
Blackboard - 19 ft. of black cloth.
Supplies - not needed but some can be borrowed.
Enrollment - 23 so far. Ungraded.

They might crowd in 30, in about
half of those who could attend. Another 25
attend the mine school and 22 can get
into the R.C. school. Total, 77 out of 125
children in the settlements on the lake.

The United Church contingent urgently needs
a two-room school with living quarters to be
built near the present site. The Church should
then be requested to demolish the old mission house.

The Narrows settlement is about ten miles
from the "ghost" town at the mine where our
sub-agent (if one is appointed) might be able to
salvage much building material. Lumber is
scarce at the Narrows. No saw-mill. The second
picture shows the R.C. Mission house at Oxford Lake,
built mainly of materials winter-hauled from God's Lake.

As a beginning, Mr. Bennett
might bring over by water two outdoor
toilets for the O.C. school.
