1948-49 Building Program - Norway House Agency

Reference your letters of December 19 and December 27 - on File 9-3

We have taken the following action with regard to the proposed building of three new day schools and teacherages in your Agency:

(a) Cross Lake N.C. Indian Day School -

We have forwarded a requisition to our Departmental Purchasing Agent for the building materials listed on your requisition. We have asked that these building materials be ordered to reach Edmonton not later than March 15, 1948. Inspector Hamilton is being forwarded a copy of this letter and is requested to approach the Lamb regarding the transportation of these supplies from Edmonton to Cross Lake.

(b) Island Lake N.C. Day School -

We have forwarded a bill of materials for this school to our Departmental Purchasing Agent with the request that the supplies reach Ilford not later than February 15, 1948. We have asked that these supplies be forwarded via Johnson Transportation Company. If Inspector Hamilton wishes to advise concerning the two other transportation companies at Ilford, we will be glad to hear from him.

Your comments concerning the gypsum board have been noted and we have substituted Ten-Tone, as required.

........... Wish
With regard to the siding for the Island Lake School, we have substituted Insul-brick for Asbestos-siding shingles. We have found that Asbestos-siding shingles sustain a great loss in shipping even on the railways. Therefore we have replaced this item with Insul-brick and hope that it will prove satisfactory. If you wish literature on the method of applying Insul-brick, I would suggest you contact the firm supplying it when you receive the purchase order.

God's Lake Barracks U.C. Day School

Unfortunately, North American Builders Limited have such a large quantity of orders from the Army and Department of Transport ahead of them, that they will not be able to build our prefabricated schools until late spring. Therefore, we have no alternative other than to place the order for this school and request that it be delivered as early in the winter as the tractor train shipments are made. We regret this action, but so many other concerns are ordering prefabricated buildings, that we must wait our turn for delivery.

I would draw your attention to the policy of the Department in naming these day schools so as to provide a minimum confusion in our filing system here. At the present time there is considerable confusion concerning the naming of the schools in your agency. For example, we are now dealing with three Cross Lake Schools, namely,

Cross Lake Residential School,
Cross Lake U. C. Day School,
Cross Lake R. C. Day School.

A similar situation exists at God's Lake, at Oxford House and at Island Lake. The inevitable errors have occurred in filing accounts, letters, etc., and in the filing of requisitions and orders.

I have discussed this matter with Major Clark and we would like to hear your views concerning other names.
for certain of your schools, similar situations have arisen in other agencies when new schools were being built. For example, we have a school at Fisher River but a new one is under construction there now. Rather than have a Fisher River No. 2, we have accepted Mr. Indian Agent Lassus's suggestion that it be named the "Burdoch Indian Bay School," after the present Chief. Major Clark suggested the name Sagitowek for one of the Cross Lake schools. We will expect to hear further from you in this regard.

Bernard F. Neary,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.

Arthur Trout - worked Sept. 23, 24, 25 - was paid $1.75; $2.50 total $4.25

Their work included:
- Tearing down the old washhouse towers
- Demolishing the stone chimney and fireplace - a remarkably substantial structure, worthy of having another house built onto it!
- Removing stones and mortar
- Covering large opening left by fireplace removal with logs and thick insulation of moss
- Closing-up and covering front door of school in similar fashion so as to make the school less drafty and more habitable
- Covering large roof from the playground
- Cutting out undergrowth which has grown up in front of and around the school
- Doubling the size of the playground by cutting down the bush
- Gathering brush in piles ready for burning

B. George Andrews (Sr.) - Sept. 23; 24; 25 rec'd $2.50; $2.50; $1.90; $2.50 - $9.45

His work included:
- Carrying & building tables in school for ending new lumber
- Repairs to the interior of the school including fixing doors to allow them to close properly, fixing hags and latches; covering windows where the panes were broken; setting up camp heater & the chimney; cleaning stove pipes etc.;
- Repairing old broken-down toilet, digging new latrine holes;
- Ditching to run off surface water.

TOTAL -(of A. & B.) $43.70

I had been instructed by Mr. E.B. Goodham to pay for the work done with orders issued on the Hudson's Bay Co., this was impossible as the H.B.C. post closed down when their manager resigned. The H.B.C. trader, Mr. Rzinski, has an outpost here in charge of an Indian. Numerous lines of goods have been cut off stock in this store therefore we have been supplying the Indians out of our own supplies. Those working here have asked that they too be allowed to receive goods in place of orders. This was done & has led, possibly, to some confusion in the appearance of my accounts. I have since made arrangements with Mr. Rzinski that all future Indian Dept. work will be paid for with orders on his outpost; his trader will forward the orders to him, and he will bill the Dept. enclosing copies of my orders, though admittedly they are not enlightening. This work has been paid for by me, therefore payment should be forwarded to me rather than to Rzinski's outpost.

Yours truly,

Howard W. Gibson.

I have just finished a long discussion with both Mr. Doucet and Mr. Clark concerning the proposed transfer of funds from the God's Lake Narrows School in the Norway House Agency to the Little Black River School in the Glandeboye Agency.

On January 7, 1948, I wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Goodman as follows:

"God's Lake Narrows U.C. Day School -

"Unfortunately, North American Builders Limited have such a large quantity of orders from the Army and Department of Transport ahead of them, that they will not be able to build our prefabricated schools until the late spring. Therefore, we have no alternative other than to place the order for this school and request that it be delivered as early in the 1948-49 winter as the tractor train shipments are made. We regret this action, but so many other concerns are ordering prefabricated buildings, that we must wait our turn for delivery."

...... AS
As you are probably aware, Mr. Clark has made an educational survey of the Norway House Agency and he has emphasized the necessity of providing a good school at God's Lake Narrows where there are a large number of children.

Mr. Goodman was also insistent for the needs of a proper school at God's Lake Narrows and it is felt that before we transfer these funds, we should have an opportunity of further discussing this problem. The present school at God's Lake Narrows is an old log building which is very dilapidated. Our records show that these Indian children have attended this school very well with an average attendance last year of approximately 26.

I would like to discuss the situation, therefore, with you when I see you in Winnipeg next week.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

God's Lake Narrows Indian Day School.

Reference your 207-48 of November 15

Immediately your letter was received here, we began to prepare an outline design for a one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence which could be erected at a lower cost than the present building.

This building will not have a full basement and will be heated by stoves and not by a furnace. It should, therefore, be much easier to erect and will serve our needs in the more northerly areas, where it is often difficult to put in a full foundation.

I have been advised by our Chief Architect that he expects the first set of these plans to be ready about the middle of January. I hope that I will have a chance to show them to you during your visit here. A bill of materials is also being prepared so that we can order the necessary building supplies for both God's Lake Narrows and for Oxford House. In the meantime, we would appreciate full shipping instructions for the supplies to be forwarded to Mr. Bennett at God's Lake.

Bernard F. Henry,

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 8th February 1943.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 16th February, 1943, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That funds are provided in the 1942-43 Appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to purchase materials for the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools and teachers' residences on the following Indian Reserves in the Norway House Agency, Province of Manitoba:

(1) Gods Lake Narrows
(2) Oxford House

That these materials require to be shipped in now to the sites of the schools by tractor train so that erection can be carried out next summer;

That these schools will be erected by local Indian day labour under the supervision of a foreman carpenter;

That every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for the materials required for the building;

That only two firms have submitted complete tenders for all materials required:

(1) Monarch Lumber Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, have quoted $11,256.72 f.o.b., Ilford, Manitoba.

(2) North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, have quoted $11,670. f.o.b. Winnipeg, Manitoba.

That the officials concerned consider the price quoted by the North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited to be the lower in spite of the varying f.o.b. points.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited, in the amount of $11,670. f.o.b. Winnipeg, for the supply of the materials necessary for the erection of the abovementioned two schools.

February 9, 1936.

Mr. G.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Clark:

We were very pleased to receive your letter today of January 23rd stating that building materials were soon to arrive for our new school. We have not yet met Mr. Superintendent Taunton of Ilford but will consult with him later regarding the new school site. In the meantime we will be prepared to look after building materials if they arrive before he does.

Tractors are unable to get closer than to the Catholic Mission or to the Hudson's Bay Co. I will try to see Mr. Roy Bennett re his suggestions for the best possible placing of the materials. They could be moved here by bombardier from where the tractor leaves them or they could be moved by barge in the spring.

The location of the buildings in your drawing was correct but you confused the church with the school. Our house is located about 75 feet back of the church. The school is at present about 200 yards west, at the entrance of the Narrows. We made a new cement foundation for our house last summer just east of the present location but didn't get the house moved. This will be done in the spring. Then we plan to tear down the old church & build a new one east of here between the house & the cemetery.

The location for the new school would be best right on the location of the present one. We could arrange that the present building be demolished as we will have no use for it other than as a school. Here you would find the best foundation as, this land having been cleared & drained for many years, should provide solid foundation. There is a good sized clearing with gardens in front. A playground is at the back. A better drainage ditch should be dug at the east side as this part is wet during spring & rainy weather. The school, if on the present location, would face south-west. That is the windows would be parallel to the shore. We do not face south here, either but somewhat westerly but get the full benefit of the heat of the sun.

Will the school have a full sized basement? This would make for a more solid foundation. It should be of the floating basement type, that is with the reinforcing steel going down the sides & into the floor & the basement & floor being one solid unit. I don't think there'll be the solid rock under that location. There isn't here either but we think that we have got down to a solid base and that most depends on clearing & draining.

May I suggest that plans also be made for a new dock at the school to be put in as early as possible as water is very low & work would be easy. The present dock was pretty well demolished by high water.

Kindest regards. Sincerely yours,

Howard B. Gibson

Re: God's Lake United Church School

We have recently received a letter from Reverend Howard B. Gibson, United Church Missionary at God's Lake. Part of his letter reads as follows:

"Tractors are unable to get closer than to the Catholic Mission or to the Hudson's Bay Co. I will try to see Mr. Roy Bennett re his suggestions for the best possible placing of the materials. They could be moved here by bombardier from where the tractor leaves them or they could be moved by barge in the spring."

Before the supplies are shipped, you should decide on the site on which the supplies should be placed, so that they will be available for construction of the building when the weather conditions permit. Mr. Gibson considers that the present building should be demolished, and the new building erected on the same site. The former agent, Mr. Goodman, suggested a different site. For your information in this regard, I attach a rough sketch prepared by Mr. Clark of this Division.

Mr. Clark feels that as buildings at God's Lake of any sort are scarce, and as he understands that there is a continual demand for them, it would be unwise to demolish the present school, which may be used for some other purpose.
However, as mentioned above, Mr. Gibson suggests that we demolish it. We are leaving the matter in your hands to decide what action is best to take in the matter.

PP/3T Attech.

To this I could not agree as it entailed extra work to no purpose and also destroyed a building in a location where buildings are scarce.

Mr. Roy Bennett, Assistant Agent, is located at God's Lake, and I have instructed him to ensure the cement and material are properly stored when they arrive at God's Lake Narrows.

DIRECTOR

Please find attached the following tenders for the construction of the Oxford House, God's Lake and Chemawawin (Cedar Lake) Indian Day Schools.

These schools are identical in that they will follow plan 888. The bills of materials are already on the ground at Oxford House and at God's Lake. These materials went in by tractor train this winter and work can begin on the schools within another fortnight.

The materials for Chemawawin on Cedar Lake are being ordered now as they will be shipped by barge from The Pas when ice clears from these rivers.

In analyzing these tenders you will find the following figures:

| CONTRACTOR     | God's Lake | Oxford House | Chemawawin |

| Emery Brothers | 6,800.     | 6,800.       | 6,400.     |

It would seem evident that we can eliminate the highest tenderer, Emery Brothers, immediately. However, there is some doubt as to whether we should accept Mr. Sabiston's or the Matthews Construction Company tenders for the God's Lake and Oxford House Schools. Mr. Sabiston is not recommended by Mr. Davis who states that when
requested to provide references, Mr. Sabiston did not return to the office as promised. I also attach a letter which I had Mr. Connelly, Supervising Engineer of Indian Health Services, prepare for me. Apparently he is a good carpenter but there is some question as to his integrity as a contractor.

Therefore, I would suggest that we only hire him for the God's Lake School construction (this will require only Ministerial approval) and have prepared submissions to Council for the other two school contracts to be awarded to the Matthews Construction Company of The Pas, Manitoba. This company is a large one, has competent crews in the field, and has already been recommended for the construction of the Nelson House Indian Day School.

I do not feel we could recommend the Matthews Company for all four schools, especially when the Sabiston tender is lower. Could I discuss this matter with you please.

Bernard F. Neary,

God's Lake

PRICES FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL.

Requesting authority for the provision of one-room Indian Day Schools on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, in the Norway House Agency; and on the Chassawin Indian Reserve, in The Pas Indian Agency, both in the Province of Manitoba, and for which funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
June 1, 1949.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, in the Norway House Indian Agency, and on the Chassawinna Indian Reserve, in the Pas Indian Agency, both in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Oxford House Reserve and on the Chassawinna Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest .........."

THAT the building materials for these schools have already been purchased and have been shipped by tractor trains to the sites of both schools;

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of both these Indian reserves, there are few builders or contractors in the area, nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT, as the result of enquiries made by our field officials, we have been able to obtain the following labour tenders for the erection of these buildings:

| Contractor                          | Oxford House | Chassawinna |
|------------------------------------|--------------|-------------|
| Matthews Construction Company, The Pas | $5,900.00    | $5,900.00   |
| Elmer Robison, Winnipeg             | $6,000.00    | -           |
| Enos Brothers, Flin Flon            | $6,000.00    | $6,400.00   |

THAT the lowest tenderer, namely the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, has building crews
In this region and is known to be a satisfactory and reliable contractor. This tender covers all transportation and boarding costs and is felt to be fair and reasonable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the erection of the Oxford House Indian Day School by the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900.00) and of the Chumashin Indian Day School by the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900.00), this being the most suitable arrangement possible at present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children on these reserves in time for school opening in September.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Clark:

We are disturbed at the suggestions that the new United Church School be moved off the Reserve. Mr. Roy Bennett, Assistant Indian Agent, intimated that the present school location was unsuitable, because of lack of solid bottom, to hold the new building. He dug two holes. He said he came to stones & water on the school property. At the location he has proposed between the Hudson's Bay Co. & the freetrader's property (Mr. Tom Rumlinski) he said he came to bed-rock. The Chief & Councillors asked permission yesterday to dig a hole on the school property. They wanted to see the nature of the soil as Mr. Bennett had filled in his hole. They dug about 50 feet west of Mr. Bennett's hole exactly on the spot that Mr. Staunton had said the school should be put. In digging down five feet they encountered heavy clay, a mixture of clay & sand & finally rocks & hard clay. They struck no moisture whatsoever. This merely proved that there is the solid bottom that we have maintained was there.

Mr. Bennett said that our new foundation for our house had spoiled this location for the new school. Let me point out two things about our house foundation: 1. We are on the slope of the hill & have experienced the same trouble as the builders had when making the new house for the Principal of Brandon Residential School. Our solution will be the same as theirs, to drain off the water which, coming downhill, has weakened the foundation. 2. The water may not have affected our foundation if we had had time last fall to move the house & thus not leave the foundation open & exposed to frost. The frost cracked it first & weakened it.
The location of the school is much different from here. It is at the top of the hill, not on the slope as we are. There is good drainage on all sides. I would suggest that if there is any doubt about this location, Mr. Glass, the district supervisor of trading posts for the Hudson's Bay Co., should be consulted. He is in charge of locating their buildings. The Hudson's Bay Co. built a new store & warehouse on their property here at the Narrows last summer. Their other building stood for 50 years. They built on similar soil to here, on the hillsides too, and not on the bedrock nearby where it is now suggested that our new school be placed. Our present school building has stood for at least 30 years & is quite solid though of hem logs. I trust that this explanation clears up any doubt that there may be for the suitability of the present school location.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) Howard B. Gibson.

This merely proved that there is the solid bottom that we have maintained was there.

Mr. Bennett said that our new foundation for our house had spoiled this location for the new school. Let me point out two things about our house foundations. 1. We are on the slope of the hill & have experienced the same trouble as the builders had when making the new house for the Principal of Brandon Residential School. Our solution will be the same as theirs, to drain off the water which, coming downhill, has weakened the foundation. 2. The water may not have affected our foundation if we had had time last fall to move the house & thus not leave the foundation open & exposed to frost. The frost cracked it first & weakened it.

The location of the school is much different from here. It is at the top of the hill, not on the slope as we are. There is good drainage on all sides. I would suggest that if there is any doubt about this location, Mr. Glass, the district supervisor of trading posts for the Hudson's Bay Co., should be consulted. He is in charge of locating their buildings. The Hudson's Bay Co. built a new store & warehouse on their property here at the Narrows last summer. Their other building stood for 50 years. They built on similar soil to here, on the hillside too, and not on the bed-rock nearby where it is now suggested that our new school be placed. Our present school building has stood for at least 30 years & is quite solid though of hewn logs. I trust that this explanation clears up any doubt that there may be for the suitability of the present school location.

Yours very truly,

Howard R. Gibson

Further reference to your letter of August 29, 1949, file No. 513-5 (E3), I recently returned from God's Lake and while there inspected the site of the above mentioned school. With reference to your telegram of Oct. 3rd, following please find information requested.

No. 1. Attendance Indian Children York Factory School.

Ten children are attending at the present time. This attendance will probably rise to twenty in the near future, as families are expected to move in from Fort Nelson.

No. 2. Progress Construction New Schools in Agency

Oxford House School, No. 1 has been completed, with the exception of installation of Selkirk chimney.

God's Lake United Church School is also completed, with exception of Selkirk chimney.

When these chimneys arrive it will be only a matter of hours to install each one.

I made a final check on God's Lake United Church School on Oct. 17th.

This building has been completed sufficiently to legalize payment to the Contractor.

However the finishing was an extremely hurried job and reflects no credit to the man concerned.

The living quarters especially are very poorly painted and finished, the cupboard doors do not fit and the paint has just been slapped on.

In the Main Class Room, the small windows on the North side are fitted with butt hinges, these hinges were not counterpaned, when the windows are closed it leaves an eighth of an inch gap.

The Contractor was told about all this by the Assistant Agent at God's Lake and agreed to rectify it, however it was not done as apparently the main idea was to get finished and get back to town.

Unfortunately, the Contractor had left when I made my final inspection. The whole finish shows a definite lack of interest.

In my opinion this man should not be given any further contracts with the Indian Department.

Dear Sir,

I have given above my usual address; but I am really writing from Grand Rapids, Man.

I sent you word either by my own writing, or by that of Mr. Archibald MacKay that Solomon Butler had left his position as teacher here, so that I desired the appointment of Rev. Mr. Fraser in his place. I find on reaching this place that Mr. Fraser has been teaching steadily since July 1st, but that he has not been notified by your Dept. of his appointment. I should be glad if you would kindly notify him, & send him any instructions that you may desire. I do not know if you can also make him dispenser of medicines & rations, &c., with the usual salary payment for that; but it would be desirable. He lives among his Indians, & is very capable; while all others live the other side of the river, & are quiet at Norway House. I have visited the school, & inspected his Registry, & find he is doing all that can be done. The numbers attending are small, but so many are constantly away & can not attend.

There is no work now at Grand Rapids, & many go away to Chetawaway & other places to hunt, fish, or make a living. I think many will be away this next winter. He is diligent.
But unless there is some great change here, that is unless the lake trout fishing revives, and the Indians are used for it, there will soon be few Indians here. There is no way for them to make a living. They might indeed grow potatoes, keep cattle, and do this for small salaries; but it seems impossible to teach them to do so.

I think that the Indian Agent might do a little more in this direction if he were really interested in his work. But my chief object in writing was to ask you to notify Mr. Fraser of his appointment as teacher, and if possible to appoint him to distribute rations, medicines, etc. I believe the Indians are deprived by the Agent in a large way of their rights or are torn away. If they could be distributed by some authority, upon condition of the Indians doing their duty as to wood for the school, it would be better. As it is there is often little or no wood for the school, and the school has been closed for want of fire. The Indians are supposed to find all the school wood. Mr. Fraser will enclose a note by you authorizing you to pay his expenses to me at Prince Albert as far more convenient for him.

I beg to remain

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge yours with enclosures, copy of letter from J. Morrison M.P.

I fail to see why you sent his letter (copy) to me. I think you can easily deal with the man. I certainly shall not answer it to him. He is evidently sure that he could not secure the post of teacher for his daughter.

I quite agree with the rule that all able-bodied young men should go to the front if possible. But any child can see that we can not spare all the men. If Mr. Gelling is selected for active service, or voluntarily enlists, I shall find another teacher. It is a matter also of wise economy. You can not pay a teacher highly; I can not afford a missionary. Between us we can support a man. School is not run in order that a daughter may remain at home!

Sir,

At the request of the members of this Reserve, and after consultation with my counsellor, I beg respectfully to request that you will consider the advisability of immediately removing the lay reader who at present functions as missionary to this Reserve.

To put it mildly, Mr. Butten's conduct betrays the utter lack of those outward signs which signify the "inner grace" that usually inspires a
minister of the Gospel.

Far from discharging any of the duties incumbent upon a missionary, he strives to render his every act and utterance entirely un-Christian and un-British.

His sermons are merely graphic descriptions of his own self-imagined qualifications and virtues, and his general attitude is that of some wonderful constellation whose rays have, for a moment, condescended to illumine the benighted lives of the untutored Indians (to whom he refers as "niggers").

Yet he is the quintessence of ignorance. His mind is so completely occupied by his pomposity and conceit that there is no room left for anything else.
To convey a comprehensive idea of Mr. Butler's character would entail the enumeration of so many acts and omissions that the recital would tire your patience, and even then the impression would not be so accurate or convincing as you could obtain from a few minutes' study of the man himself.

It is also difficult to embody in any specific charge the many acts and peculiarities of character which have made Mr. Butler's presence at Grand Rapids undesirable as a missionary, a resident, or in any capacity at all.

But in order that an investigation may be made I will state one or two facts.
the examination of which will elicit such additional information as will convince you of the necessity of dealing with Mrs. Butcher's services immediately.

Mrs. Butcher is the official school teacher appointed by the Indian Department. She kept school three times only during the first half of the year, and has not held any session at all since Treaty Day. Mrs. Butcher occasionally attends school, but it is usually only to distribute biscuits.

2. Notwithstanding the generous supply given by the Department, Mrs. Butcher not only refuses to visit the sick and personally to
attend to their complaints, but he declines even to issue medicines at all. This customary reply to a request for medical attention is that the medicines are supplied "not for you niggers," but for the exclusive use of Mr. Butcher and his family.

3. Charitable gifts, sent for distribution to the Indians, are sold by Mr. Butcher.

4. His attitude to the Indians is insulting, abusive and altogether intolerable. None of the white people will have anything at all to do with him.

Since Mr. Butcher owes his appointment to the

This half-breed settlement, of course, would have nothing to do with the Indian Department, but I expect that there will not be a provincial school for their use. As a rule half-breed school districts are in difficulties over their taxes, and if this should be the case there may be one or two half breed children attending the reserve school. Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Mrs Gentleman and myself reached this reserve last week after having to spend three days in a fishing camp in Lake Winnipeg, and doing the last 90 miles in an open gas trailer in a heavy sea, and spending $300 in travelling expenses since leaving Gleichen.

I am taking the liberty of sending a requisition for school material direct as there is nothing on hand whatever, and I learned in Selkirk that the Agent would be here on August 18th, and that also he would be away paying treaty in the meantime, and of course it would take him a few days to return, and the list may be delayed in his office. If as I have stated same can be filled there is just time to get the material up on the last boat of the Northern Fish Co., the first week in September. To wait until the agent came up would mean that material could not reach me until the October mail came from the Pas, and I think it is 90¢ a ewt from the Pas alone, while from Selkirk it is only 50¢ a ewt.

I have asked for enough material for a year, or six months at least. From what I have seen of the people there must be about 25 children of school age on the reserve, and by the looks of things school matters seem to have got to a somewhat slack stage. I don't think it is entirely the fault of the people. I observe that they all speak English, even the old women, which is somewhat unusual. They certainly appear to take a little more interest in life in general than the Blackfeet. I met several of the people with their families on Sandy Island fishing for the Northern Co., and making good wages. The Wolverine also has two deckhands belonging to this place.

The schoolhouse is a log shanty, I should say about 16 by 22. It contains twelve desks of which four are broken, one map of Manitoba, one stove, and a piece of blackboard about 5' by 7', and is lighted by four small windows, two on each side. The floor goes this way—and the ceiling this way—and the chief tells me that it was built when he was a boy, as near as I can make out about 35 years ago. From conversations I have had with the people I see no reason why they should not take as much interest in school matters as other bands do, and I conclude that Mr. Bunn is correct in his statement in his letter that they would do so if some interest was taken by their teacher. They have not had anything of a school concert, school fair, or school sports, and on the
whole, for the last few years at least, have had little encouragement in their school. The place is unfenced, and no school garden attempted, and every family has crowds of dogs, who do the work of horses.

On the other side of the river there is the townsite of Grand Rapids in which there is a public school under the control of the Commissioner for Northern Manitoba. This school has been from time to time opened, teacher coming in and remaining three months as there is no house, and they have to board with the people. These people with one exception, are non treaty Indians. The provincial dept. cannot get their taxes, and it is no good to sell them out as no one would make an offer for lots in this part of the world.

I observe that some of the children's names appear on our register, and the people seem anxious to combine the two schools if that could be possible. Mr Buteher told me that the provincial dept. have made several attempts to open up without getting much result, on the other hand the people say that either at Cedar lake or another reserve between here and the Pas, the pupils from the public school and the Indian school have been combined, and have made a very good school. There are I am told about 20 children of school age over the river.

The location of our schoolhouse is at one end of the reserve, Mr Buteher telling me that in the spring and fall it is impossible for either teacher or pupils to reach it on account of sloughs and water. The mission house that I am occupying is at the other end of the reserve. Both are too old to move, and the church will have to build a new house sooner or later. A good log school and teachers house could be built in a dry central location at a very small cost, as there are plenty of logs close, and also several empty houses the upper logs of which should be in good order.

I understand that it has been the custom of certain of the Indians to complain, over something or other, which might continue after the first six months. Before we arrived I am told that it was said that if they don't like us, they will soon get someone else. Do not take any notice of these matters. I can assure you that I would not think of spending out all this money without the intention of doing our very best. I will be careful not to give cause for them to complain, but I know that some Indians get cranky over nothing at all. From what I have seen of the children they look to me to be some good material to work upon, and I hope I shall get results which will meet with your satisfaction, as well as those of the parents.

Yours faithfully,

In this case also, I have done the best possible under the circumstances, as there is nothing here. There are still more children over the river, but whom I must refuse for the simple reason that there is no room inside to place their seats.

I also find that the children are very backward, and that for some years past there appears to have been very little order kept in the schoolhouse, which makes things somewhat difficult, as most of the children are young, and appear to have looked upon the school as a play-place. Dear Mr. Perrier,

I must thank you for your encouraging letter of September 9th, which reached me on October 14th.

In reply, I should say that there are 20 half-breed children on the other side of the river, of school age. Their parents, disposed of their lots just before the war, and would be termed squatters. They live by hunting and fishing as the Indians do, and the children are all Cree speaking, and are much more backward than the Indian children. The matter of crossing the river in the spring and fall varies. I am told that there might be a week or ten days during which they cannot cross, but this year the river on the 17th was entirely open, and on the 26th, the people were crossing on the ice. There is a public school building in Grand Rapids village, but it is not up to much. They have pretty well ruined it by using it as a dance hall. The last teacher they had over there left in February last, after three months work. The Manitoba Government seems to have had a number of teachers from time to time, but none stay longer than a quarter. There is no place at which a teacher could board.

I have had about a dozen of these half-breed children over into our school. They are making progress, and the arrangement gives the settlement some satisfaction. Their parents have been putting them over daily. Please inform me, if I may send a return of this attendance of half-breed children to the Provincial Educational department. That department, I suppose, would include Grand Rapids village in its grants to the public school, and they might send me a cheque, which would come very acceptable, as my expenses during the past six months have been heavy.

I conclude that you would take up the subject of a combined school with the Provincial authority, with the suggestion that they should in future undertake part of the expenses, which would be only right. I should also say that the Public school has never been inspected by a Provincial Inspector, and they would thus not be in a position to say much about the state of the children's education on the other side.

I find that within the past few weeks in our own school we have been able to do little work after 2-30 in the afternoon as it gets so dark. The windows are so small, and the thick bush on two sides does not help much.

I am issuing rations, which the Agent had placed in the school at treaty time, and the people are calling upon Mrs Gentleman for drugs, and things when children are sick, but as so few of these things were sent in I am told, we are having to give them out from our own small stores.

There appears also to be some need among the people for clothing. There are a couple of traders in the settlement, but in neither, are any dry-goods kept. Both these stores are in a very
In any way of business with supplies limited to flour, sugar & tea.

At John Smith's we received yearly from the Agency, a bolt of print, serge, galathea, some pants, & some blankets. Nothing of that appears to come to this place, and it would be really a help if such could be granted. Mrs Gentleman and myself have given away everything that we really can spare. I am badly in need of blankets for the old people, and some pants for the boys. One of the girls appears at school with a bathing costume worn as a jumper with only a little coat and skirt. I have gone to some trouble to find out the reason, and it seems that it is partly owing to there being nothing nearer than the Pas, and also the poor fishing. Neither the fishing or the hunting is what it used to be years ago.

I observe that the people have a few head of cattle, which they care for themselves, which I think will be helpful to them in years to come, and if the matter of new buildings is considered by the Department it might be pointed out that this band have in the past not called upon the Department to any great extent, also that they show some inclination to take care of what they have got, which is not always the case. They appear to me to be a band well worthy of consideration, and an Improved day school would work fine. They are poor, about the poorest I have come across, but this I feel is due to their location. I suppose in the early days, hunting and fishing was good. Sooner or later they will have to take to the farming and cattle industry, and the school should be a means to bring this more before them.

From this information I trust you will be able to convince those who have the estimates in hand for another year, but if there any other details needed, I would be glad to supply them or send them to the Agent whichever you desire.

Dear Sir:

I must thank you for your letter of November 2nd, which reached me by the last mail, and the enclosures therein.

Regarding school matters I am glad to see that the Department have under consideration these difficulties, and the report referred to me is, I expect that which required the number and ages of the children on both sides of the river, which I forwarded to Ottawa by the last mail.

Therein, I endeavoured to make clear that the present standing of the school in every respect, is by no means as high as other Department schools in the western provinces. The present pupils in attendance have always been crowded so close together, that the order and discipline of the school is very low, and that the progress which should be made, is not made. I am not surprised that under the present conditions that teachers in the past have become more or less discouraged, and the parents have been inclined to complain, certainly in my experience with other Indian children, there is much to be desired as regards the pupils here.

I observe that the Department are willing to provide such material suitable for instruction with regards local conditions and I had in mind a compass mariners, maps and charts of Lake Winnipeg and signal books, most of which can be supplied by the Department of Marine and Fisheries at very low cost, all of which would be most useful to these boys. The provision of such things I would not suggest at the present time, owing to the lack of space, also the boys should advance at least as far as the third reader.

There have been several years, which I have observed that all the children in the various schools are from ten to fourteen with few younger ones. As time goes on this changes and the elder children's places are taken by smaller children, hence the suitability of adjustable steel desks, which provide suitable seating for all ages at all times. Single adjustable desks, steel, as used in the public schools of Winnipeg cost about $8.50 each. Cast iron ended desks are an expense to the Department. This school as you know is cold from Friday to Monday, and the frost snaps the iron ends, two more having gone within the past few weeks. I have screwed some down but the floor is so soft, that they don't hold long.

From the enclosed returned you will observe that the average attendance has been maintained, also a number of children from over the river have come across. I notice that the Department desire the Indian children to have first consideration and with this in view, I have kept the Indian children's places, and permitted the half-breed children to occupy whatever space might be at disposal. Drill and exercises cannot be carried out during the winter months. The children have never done any singing, but I can obtain an organ next summer.
In event of a new school being decided upon, I would also suggest that a move be made from the present sight, a little more than a quarter of a mile north, and placed facing the harbour mouth. Such a location would be within easy distance of all families on both sides, and about midway between the two churches. The entrance to the river and harbour is not buoyed, or marked and the last time the Wolverine came in she struck. The situation is such that a new building would make a splendid mark if placed in the correct position, and I think the Marine and Fisheries Department would be glad to have our Department assist them in this regard. As you know the river comes in at one corner of the harbour, and buildings placed in view of same are more noticeable than in the bush.

The Department have no other buildings on the reserve at present, and I have placed the rations in the small attic.

Regarding the medicines, I have not seen Mr McKay, who is away but I have arranged with an Indian to bring them over. I don't think you have ever been in this house. We have really no place for them and everything freezes. I have papered the place, and keep three stoves going, but all our potatoes are frozen as well as our years supplies of canned fruit and milk. There is practically only one room in the house that we can keep warm. I understand that there are very few medicines on hand; these will keep under the best possible present conditions.

I might also say that this is the first Indian school I have experienced in which none of the children have bad necks, or sores. There is one boy, almost past school age, a cripple whom I think is bad, but otherwise the children appear to be more healthy than others I have met with. Perhaps it is the use of fish oil.

I quite understand that whatever the Department can do will have to wait until the lake opens up. You will be able to advise the Department that whatever is done, plans would have to be made very carefully, and very fully, as the distance from Selkirk, or the Pas does not permit material to be mislaid, but I expect between now and summer such matters will have been fully covered.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Perrier,

One of the difficulties in connection with this place is getting in household supplies; it is impossible to get stuff from the Pas, which compels one to order from Winnipeg to take advantage of a boat that runs at odd times during the month of August only direct from Selkirk to the mouth of the river. I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the educational facilities at Grand Rapids. I have noted the suggestion that Mr. P. H. Gentleman, teacher of the Indian day school, devote half his time to the public school across the river. In reply I have to inform you that the Department has had some correspondence with Mr. Gentleman in this connection and it is considered that there is a sufficient number of children on each side of the river at Grand Rapids to warrant two day schools. It is impracticable to have a combined public and Indian school, because of the difficulties of crossing the river at certain seasons of the year. Further, the Department considers that all of Mr. Gentleman's time is required for the Indian work.

I might inform you that the teacher of the Indian school, with our permission, has allowed a few children from the white settlement on the north side of the river to attend his classes. He has been instructed, however, that these children must not crowd the accommodation of the Indian pupils or interfere with the instruction of our wards.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Grand Rapids, Manitoba, September 20th, 1924.

Mr. Ferrier,

The September mail reached us a few days ago, but did not contain any correspondence regarding the school. I rather expected something from Commissioner Graham, but I wanted to write you on other matters, as I think it best to keep you informed. I wished to make it clear to Commissioner Graham that any work done at this place must take advantage of the boat that runs only in July and August.

However other matters. By this time I expect you have received a visit from the Bishop of Saskatchewan, who was here on August 17th. At that time the Bishop had requests of a threefold nature. First that he should place an ordained man in charge of the Church work, Second, that I should continue the teaching, with which the people were well satisfied; Third, that he should use his influence with the Manitoba Government to have a teacher appointed for the village school of Grand Rapids over the river. His Lordship noted these requests, and told them of the shortage of ordained men, and I believe expressed some intention of calling on the Manitoba Educational Dept to see what the position was regarding the Public school.

Besides the visit of the Bishop the settlement has been visited by Mr. Bracken, Prime Minister of Manitoba, and Mr. Black, the member, and then later by Commissioner Campbell, whose office has now been discontinued by the Manitoba Government. The request for a teacher over the river was put up to the ministers by Henry Mackay, and they appear to have promised them a teacher. In this request the Mackay family are entirely alone, the rest of the settlement (which really consists of non-treaty Indians) are entirely satisfied with the present arrangement. When Commissioner Campbell came along from the Pan, I understood that it appeared that the Ministers had made various promises, and then left him to carry them out, which put him in a bad way unless they voted the money; briefly he was the "goat". I asked him to let me know what the Winnipeg authorities intended doing, and by this mail I have word of his being out of office but that it had been suggested that I should teach six months on each side of the river using their old schoolhouse. This I think is the outcome of some expression on the part of the other halfbreeds who met the Ministers, and Commissioner Campbell at the Fishing Camp at Horse Island, at which time they asked that even if a teacher was appointed, members to the public school, would they be allowed to send their children across the river. Of course I believe they were told that the question would have to be answered by the I.D., but as far as I can see the Manitoba Government have suddenly woke up to the fact that it would be a piece of foolishness to have two teachers in the settlement costing round about a thousand each, when one man could do the work, and they will be looking for a way out of the difficulty. Their main difficulty is with Henry Mackay. He won't be satisfied with anything less than a teacher who will board at his place, and a combined school on either side would not satisfy him.

When the late Archdeacon Mackay advised me regarding conditions here, he referred to considerable difficulty over Church matters over the river, which he hoped I might avoid, so when the halfbreed people asked me to take in their children, I agreed while they had no teacher, and were also willing to occupy somewhat restricted space, my object being to avoid any offence, and I thought it would only be for a short while in any case.

Now there is the mission work, which of course the Bishop has in view. He did not promise them an ordained man, but at present our clergyman comes from the Pas when he can, and it would be a saving of travelling expenses, and perhaps satisfy all quarters if they did have an ordained man, and this I have suggested to the Bishop. I understand from Mr. Frazer, our clergyman at the Pas mission, that you intend building a new dayschool at the Pas next year. They have two ordained men at the Pas, and that school could be very well taught by a layman, and in view of all these circumstances I have asked the Bishop if it would not be better to get an ordained man for this place and let us go to the Pas. The three authorities, that is yourselves, the Manitoba Government, and the Bishop would have to come to some arrangement about this place either combined or otherwise, and as far as I can see Mr. Henry Mackay will not be happy unless it is otherwise.

However, I wish to go home to England for a visit next summer holidays. My Mother is getting on in years, and I should make the trip. To do so, I might have to apply to the Bank of Montreal for a loan. I have been a customer of theirs since 1911, and have never applied for a loan before. I have a fully paid up insurance policy for a fair amount, but of course I should not be able to obtain this unless I was certain of a future post. I would like if possible to leave here at the end of June, and open up your new school at the Pas on September last next year. I expect you will think I am looking ahead a bit, but by the time this gets considered by the different parties, it will be along into January or February, and then I want, if I can arrange with the Church to have some of my heavy furniture taken over, and our April and May mail is very uncertain. I am also concerned about the health of Mrs. Gentleman which is not as well as I would like; she is well, but we would like to be closer to the Doctor if that is possible.

Mr. Frazer told me that the Pas people seem to be serious in their desire for a dayschool. I thought at first it was merely talk and worry, similar to the village school difficulty at this place, but if they are serious, I feel sure my experience could be of some help, and in that place a teacher would be free from ration troubles, and various other kinds of difficulties. I would help them in the church of course if needed, but I would not be responsible for that work as I am here. I have a good deal of school equipment of my own, picture machine, woodworking bench, and I hope to pick up some other useful helps either in the east, or at home next summer.

I hope you will be able to give us careful consideration, and advise us what would be best; I shall likely not receive your answer before December, and it would be by the January mail before I could reply.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I duly received your letter of January 29th, and note that a decision has been reached to place the school, and teachers living together at this place, which I think will remove a great deal of past difficulties.

I much regret to say that my wife's health still causes me considerable anxiety. These people are not of a type that one would care to have in the house, even if it was possible to get them, and the schoolhouse is twenty-five minutes walk from the house, thus Mrs Gentleman is entirely alone the whole of the day, which I fear is not very helpful.

I do not think it possible that her health will allow us to return to such a remote place as this is, but there are a few reserves that might be considered, if they should happen to become vacant, such as the headquarters of Carlton Agency, Fisher River, or the Pas, if a school is built there. In such places there is medical advice, and also the possibility of getting some household assistance.

The teachers at Fisher River and Carlton would, I feel sure do, satisfactory work, I have met them both, and there would be no need for a change at those places, and under the circumstances I fear that we must retire from the work, unless a suitable school becomes vacant at a later date.

I would like, however, to know if I am correctly informed that under a Civil Service Insurance Act of 1914, employees retired after serving ten years or upward become entitled to a pension of ten-fiftieths of the average salary of the last three years, and also if, under such an act an allowance can be made to myself and my wife, if my wife's health does not permit a return to the west. Mrs Gentleman has not been well for the past three years but it appears to have become to be an accepted thing among the people that the wife of the teacher should visit the sick, and assist the Indian women with all kinds of their difficulties, and troubles. Since 1913 we have been entirely at their call at all hours, except during the time we spent at the Blackfoot reserve when the children required entire attention.

I have no other interest or undertakings, or other business of any kind. My entire time has been given to the Department. I mention this because I have met so many men who have run farms on a side line to which they could retire to.

I would like to take the opportunity to talk over this matter, or other possible work, on the way to Montreal, and would arrange to stop over a day in Ottawa, as near as I can tell at present on the 9th or 10th of July. It is quite possible that if we could manage to miss one western winter, my wife's health may allow us to take up the work again next spring.

Yours faithfully,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned to Prince Albert after a long round of the Indian Mission of the North.

GRAND RAPIDS RESERVE

I found everyone here has a good word to say for Mr. Wyatt. His wife and two boys joined him this summer coming via Winnipeg, and they are a thoroughly nice family with two well behaved little boys. I had no opportunity to inspect the school children but everyone seemed to be pleased with the progress made. The house however is quite unsatisfactory. The building itself is log and built backwards road to the lake front. The inside is quite unfinished and unfit for anyone to live in as it is. I found all his winter supplies and all the new mission furniture in the new school building where they are living, and after going carefully into the whole matter, I instructed him to stay where he was in the new school building until his house was properly finished and if necessary have the desks moved up to the old school building until the house was ready. Who is to blame for this I do not wish to say but a little checking up of the Indian Agent in Winnipeg would not do any harm. That Reserve is a very isolated one during seven months of the year and when we do get a really good teacher for places like that we want to keep them satisfied.

G. E. Saskatchewan.

Sir,

January 17th, 1928.

My dear Sir,

Mr. Charles Wyatt the Teacher on the Grand Rapids Indian Reserve at the mouth of the Saskatchewan River has been in the hospital at the Pas for nearly three months. A message from Rural Dean Fraser of the Pas reached me yesterday that he had died in the hospital.

Mr. Wyatt was originally in the Imperial forces and after receiving his education as a Teacher was discharged as fit and therefore there is no help to be expected from that quarter either for the expense of his sickness or for the widow. In fact I hardly think any claim for sickness would lie with the Imperial authorities because there is no doubt that he caught this congestion by exposure at Grand Rapids.

He looked after the Sunday school on the Reserve and for this the Church paid him $250 per annum beyond the Indian Dept stipend.

The Hospital secretary has sent me the enclosed bill but we certainly cannot and could not pay this from our Mission Funds. I am sending Rural Dean Fraser a grant of $100 to help the widow pay the necessary expenses of the funeral at the Pas but I think the hospital bill ought to come from the Department.

The widow has two boys at Grand Rapids and it will be impossible for them to move out of the house during the winter months, neither would it be possible for us to send in another teacher yet awhile.

The Indian Agent at Winnipeg got Mrs. Wyatt leave to go on with the teaching as long as the husband was in the hospital and I would suggest that she be allowed to continue teaching the school until the end of June when the school closes for the summer holidays.

If the Department would do these two things it would be a great help in the time of need.

Very faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Bishop Lloyd:

I was much grieved when I read your letter of the 13th instant concerning the death of Mr. Charles Wyatt, formerly missionary teacher at Grand Rapids. All reports concerning his work were very satisfactory. I greatly regret that the Department has no authority to issue a cheque to cover his hospital expenses. I am sure Your Lordship understands that the expenditure of parliamentary appropriation is under keen scrutiny and must not be used for purposes other than those for which the money was voted.

Your Lordship will know that I am very sympathetic when I inform you that full salary has been allowed since the first of September. I am also directing that the Department's approval be given for the engagement of Mrs. Wyatt until the end of June.

Selkirk, Man., 25th January, 1928

Sir:

Referring to my letter of 14th instant, I have received a letter from Mrs. C. Wyatt, wife of the late teacher at the Grand Rapids Indian Day School, in which she says:

"I will continue to teach at Grand Rapids until you say otherwise. My future plans I do not know, I only know I must find a position somewhere to keep my little boys. I want work in the Indian work if possible. My dear husband loved the Indian work and working with him, I got to like it too. If you hear of a vacancy, I would be glad to hear about it, because it is the boys that I worry about, they must be seen to."

As Mrs. Wyatt is willing to carry on with the School I would recommend that her temporary appointment be extended at least until the end of the present term, at the same salary as her late husband was receiving, $95.00 per month. By that time she will be better able to decide whether she will remain, or a vacancy may occur which would be more suitable.

Mrs. Wyatt has done splendid work at Grand Rapids among the Indian women and girls.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

On return of Department Cheque No. 3645, Vote 292, Grand Rapids, amt. $100.00 to Nathan Settee, you will note that I endorsed this over to Rev. John R. Settee for payment to Nathan Settee's widow.

This man died at Grand Rapids and the cheque followed his wife to Cumberland. There was no estate. On the cheque being endorsed by the Rev. Fraser, Settee and myself, the bank agreed to cash it for use of the widow.

I have the honor to be,

Gentlemen,

I have been notified by my bankers, The Dominion Bank, Selkirk, man., that on the 29th. ult. they received a cheque for $95.00 from you. Presumably this is for the quarter ending Sept. 30., but you will notice in my report that school was held during July and August, according to instructions received through Mr. Indian Agent Stevenson (Claudeby & Agency). My salary is $95.00 per month, $285 per quarter.

I should be glad if you would have this adjusted as soon as possible, remitting direct to the bank.

I remain,

Yours Truly,

R.T.B. Horsefield
Ottawa, December 2nd, 1929.

Reverend Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th ultimo, with reference to the payment of $95.00 recently sent to the Dominion Bank, Selkirk, Man., to your credit covering your salary as teacher of the Grand Rapids Indian Day School for the quarter ended September 30th, last.

Last March, Mr. Agent Stevenson wrote the Department, stating that you had been obliged to take your wife to the hospital at Saskatoon and he stated in his letter that you requested leave of absence and had advised him that you would make up lost time during the summer holidays. Under these circumstances and as the Department thought that you possibly required the money at the time, you were allowed salary for the full March quarter, viz., $285.00. Information on hand shows that the school was closed from early in February and you were, therefore, allowed salary for two months of the March quarter during which the school was not open. The extra period you taught the school during the September quarter was considered as making up the time lost in the March quarter and the Department feels that salary for one month in the September quarter was all to which you were entitled.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Teacher,
Indian Day School,

Seikirk, Man., August 9th, 1934.

Sir:—

I beg to advise that I inspected these buildings when the treaty payments were being made and can assure you that the requirements requested by the Rev. Mr. Armstrong are badly needed; there was no wire screening for the school house windows as a result of which the windows had to be kept down all the time, causing uncomfortable heat and stuffiness in the school room, several pains of glass were missing from the windows, and Mr. Armstrong had them covered with boards. The floor was also in bad condition and would be greatly improved by two coats of paint.

The house is also in bad repair and the things asked for in this requisition are very necessary, in order to brighten up the place as well as to make it warm, clean and comfortable for the family to live in. Although I hesitate to ask the Department to incur this expenditure, yet knowing as I do the splendid work these people are doing on the Reserve, and their inability to live comfortably without these improvements, I have no alternative, but to strongly recommend to the Department, that if at all possible, their request be acceded to and the order filled.

If approved kindly advise earliest convenience, and oblige.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,

Extract from Memorandum from Dr. P. E. Moore,
DIRECTOR OF INDIAN HEALTH SERVICES, dated 15 September, 1947.

(Orig. on 76-128)

Grand Rapids

Here we learned that the new teacher for our Department, Mr. Noel Thomas, had arrived two weeks before and was not living on the reserve. We secured a boat and crossing the river, met Mr. Thomas, his wife and three small children. The house after being empty for three years is quite in need of the renovation they are now giving it. To date only a part of their furniture has arrived. In my opinion this couple should fit in very well here and do very good work.

In company with Mr. Thomas, I visited the house of those who were sick.

The school here, with twenty-nine pupils (the expected registration) will have about 25% of air space for each pupil as given by the Health Department as the minimum requirement per pupil. It would seem a bit ironical to endeavor to clean up Tuberculosis and then crowd our children into a place like this.

I examined the school across the river, which is well located. It is built of logs, placed on a cement foundation, and has stood there since 1914. It is still in excellent condition except for needing new shingling. This building bears out a suggestion I made some time ago that all log buildings should be placed on a cement foundation. It seems to me that this applies particularly to The Pas where building material is, or should be, readily available. New houses are being put up with no supervision as to a suitable foundation, or as to size, bearing in mind the number in the family who are going to occupy the building.

School. Have said in the past about all I can say about this building. There are 56 pupils on the roll in a room which seats about half this number and all these seats are homemade and very poorly made at that.

On March 30, last, the late Indian Commissioner, Hon. David Laird, wrote, asking you to select a teacher to take charge of the Hollow Water River school after the end of the current quarter.

The Department desires to raise the standard of the day schools and for its part is prepared to pay better salaries where qualified and efficient teachers, preferably with professional training, are engaged. Am writing today. This school has been taught since last November without a day's vacation. I have acknowledged the receipt of your letter of Jan 1st, and in reply I beg to say that I am enclosing the blue print you sent me with the position of school building and teachers residence located thereon.

As you will observe by referring to the blue print neither of the buildings are located on the school lot. This lot is composed largely of high rocks and marsh and there are no buildings on it as nearly as I can tell.

The councillor, John Hardisty, informs me that in 1898 Mr. Coll, the Department's Commissioner, recommended the transfer to the new site where a small, surveyed plot was allotted by the Indians for the school building and one likewise for the teachers residence. Mr. Coll superintended the erection of the school building upon the new site. These plots, I should estimate, are from ten to fifteen yards in width and extend about one hundred yards, but there are no marks and no plat to go by.

There should be space reserved for a school garden and for a teachers garden as the soil is rich surrounding the buildings.

The teachers residence is in very poor condition being old and rotten and almost devoid of shingles. It is uninhabitable in summer in its present condition. There are no storm doors or windows and no water closet, store room, stable or wood house.

The school building is in fair condition but always somewhat in violent winds and has no entry and no storm doors or windows and is very old.

Being an ordained clergyman I accepted this school solely with the understanding that work of...
a missionary character was to be in my charge, especially Sunday services for Bible study. With this understanding my wife and I came at our own expense from Bridgeport, Connecticut to take this school. Outside of the salary of $50.00 as teacher our work is without remuneration from any source. We do it purely from a sense of duty, and of the Indians' great need and at the request of the Indians themselves.

Sometime in October a man was sent here by the Bishop to read services and he demanded the use of the school building. This I granted on condition that both he and the Commissioner become personally responsible for school property during the services, and that spitting upon the floor, walls, and furniture be prohibited.

Their promise was not kept,—articles were stolen from the school-room, biscuit boxes were broken open, the school desks were wrenched loose from the floor and several of them were completely broken down while the floor, walls, desks, and biscuit boxes were marked by spitting, much of it diseased.

After the Bishop's visit and his statements referred to in my letter of Jan 5th, I was obliged to close the school building for all services over which I do not have charge, until I receive definite instructions from the Department. This was absolutely necessary for the maintenance of order in the school-room, the protection of school material and the preservation of the health of the pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Arthur Santonius,
Teacher

P.S. Permit me to say that Mrs. Santonier assists me in beautifying and rendering comfortable the schoolroom. It is kept scrupulously clean and neat and the walls are adorned with pictures which are changed occasionally to prevent monotony. After two days and several evenings of work we repaired the desks and screwed them to the floor where they remain in position.

Every child on the roll is attending every day. We give rewards for regular attendance and also for punctuality.

While writing this letter I am informed by an Indian who has a boy in the school that a council meeting is to be held tonight at the Councillors house for the two-fold purpose of expressing pleasure at the progress that the pupils are making, and to devise ways and means for bringing the scattered population together for the purpose of attending the school.

Dear Sir:

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report signed by Mr. H.D. Cumming, Provincial Government School Inspector, Manitoba. The report is on the Hollow Water Indian Day School, and is anything but encouraging, and goes to show that it is only a waste of money employing teachers of this class in our Indian Schools.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Rev. R.W. Gardner arrived at Hollow Water River Reserve to take up the work as Missionary Teacher on September 20th and has since been in residence. He has found it impossible to begin actual teaching work until Monday last, Oct. 14th, when he expected to open school. In a letter of the 10th inst., he goes somewhat fully into the condition of things in consequence of which he could not begin actual teaching. He says there was scarcely a sound desk and the greater number were badly broken and beyond repair. Bolts have gone from the stoves, screws also were needed. These he had sent away for as advised by the Agent, but they had not arrived. Storm windows had been provided for the school but had not been fitted. This he has done himself with voluntary assistance. He states that the schoolhouse is well built but there are no water closets for the scholars. School supplies are also needed and these he is applying for, I understand, through the Agent.

With regard to qualifications, Mr. Gardner received his training in Newfoundland where he taught for a number of years. He has taught several years at the school in York Factory and several years also at Churchill for which the Department sent some school supplies, though the school was never put on your list. He has shown special fitness for teaching work. I shall be glad to hear from you as to the amount of salary that will be allowed him. This had better be sent as hitherto to Canon Lofthouse at our Synod Office here. I presume that in view of the work he has had to do to get the school ready for its use that he will be entitled to his salary from the Department from the date of his arrival.

I beg to remain,

Most faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to your efforts to secure a position as teacher in an Indian school and requesting the Department to assist you financially at the present time.

I may say that there is no superannuation scheme for teachers of Indian day schools and the most that could be done in your case would be to grant you two months' salary, or $150 gratuity upon your retirement. I wish to point out, however, that it would not be possible to engage you again in an Indian day school if such a retiring payment were made. You will understand that such a gratuity is given only when an employee leaves the service.

Although it is some time since you left the Hollow Water Indian Day School - some 10 months - I will be glad to seek the approval of the Deputy Superintendent General of a two months' gratuity, if you reply that you would be glad to have this payment at this time. You will understand that we could not appoint you to an Indian day school in future if you accept retiring leave.

I am returning Dr. Westgate's letter to you.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa,
September 19, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Hollowwater River Indian Day School, No. 515.

The Department has just been advised of the death of the teacher, Mr. R.C. Marsh. I am not certain if he operated the school for any period during the month of September. I am writing to the Agent for information regarding this and in the event of any salary being due I will advise you later.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, 10th December, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Hollow Water River Indian Day School No. 515

Mr. Emil Planckaert is appointed teacher of this school at a salary of $75.00 a month plus bonus effective September 24th, 1945. Enclosed is copy of letter of appointment.

Owing to the isolated condition of this school the other forms have not yet been received but in view of the length of time this man has been teaching without receiving any pay, I feel that payment should be made to him and his salary can be adjusted, if necessary, when the forms are received.

Please note the cheque should be drawn in his favour and forwarded to him in care of Right Rev. J. Lofthouse, D.D., Bishop of Keewatin, Bishopstowe, Kenora, Ontario.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, July 23, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Hollow Water River Indian Day School No.515.

Please note that the teacher, Mr. E. Planckert has given up duties at the above school, effective July 1st, 1946 and no further payment of salary should be made to him.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, 4 January 1947.

Memorandum:

Re: Hollow Water River C.E. Day School No. 515

Mr. Robert H. Marsh has been appointed teacher effective Jan. 1, 1947, at a salary of $118.00 a teaching month.

Enclosed are T.D. 1 Form and Staff Questionnaire Form.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, December 23, 1946.

Dear Bishop Lofthouse:

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, the Department approves the appointment of Robert Henry Marsh as teacher of the Hollowwater River C.E. Day School. Salary will be allowed him at the rate of $118.00 a teaching month effective January 1, 1947.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rt. Rev. J. Lofthouse, D.D.,
Bishop of Keewatin,
Bishopstowe,
Kenora, Ontario.
Ottawa, February 3rd, 1947.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Hollow Water River - No.552

In memorandum dated January 4th, we advised you of the appointment of Mr. R.H. Marsh, as teacher at the above mentioned school.

In future his salary cheques should be drawn in his own favor and forwarded to Rt. Rev. J. Lofthouse, D.D., Bishop of Keewatin, Bishopstow, Kenora, Ontario.

Memo for Department,

The Rev. Ed. Thomas reported that the new schoolhouse which was erected on the Hollow Water River Reserve under his supervision is completed and handed in his accounts, but it was found that they were not complete inasmuch as they were not supported by receipts for the wages paid by him. As the appropriation from which these vouchers are to be paid will soon lapse, and it is impossible to obtain those receipts within the time owing to the distant location of this Reserve, I therefore thought it best to put the vouchers through in their present shape. Dear Sir:

Last week-end I visited Hollow Water River, spending Sunday and Monday there. I found the school building in good condition, but the teacher's residence is very much in need of repair; there are leaks in the roof between the kitchen and the main building, and the joints of the logs will have to be re-plastered before the house can be used for the winter.

I have written to Mr. Peter Harper in reference to his transfer to the school at this point, and have suggested that he should endeavour to move as early as possible in order that he may have time to repair the house before the winter comes.

Would it be possible for the Department to make a grant of say $50.00 for necessary repairs. The mission house is the only possible place for the teacher to stay, and it must be repaired for the winter. We should be grateful if the Department can assist us in the matter of repairs.
